TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer the Minister to the report in the Canberra Times today which claims that according to some sources the Australian Taxation Office may be forgoing very large sums of money because of staff shortages and that these shortages are to be made even more severe by the further cuts announced last week. I further refer the Minister to the Auditor-General's report which is strewn with examples of false economies where staff ceilings have cost the Commonwealth more in uncollected revenue than it has saved. What action is proposed to ascertain further the seriousness of this problem? What action is proposed to remedy it in connection with particular departments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that there is a claim in the Press today with regard to $1,000m worth of taxes not being collected because of staff shortages. In response to a Press query this morning, the Treasurer stated that there was no factual evidence to support that allegation and that he could not substantiate a figure of that magnitude with regard to uncollected taxes caused by staff shortages.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the more general question raised by Senator Button in connection with comments in the Auditor-General's report, the recent announcements by the Government on staff measures through the Cabinet Review of Commonwealth Functions are matters to be discussed between the heads of departments, the Ministers and the Public Service Board. What this will require is that the staff that is available in the departments will be there to give the service that is required. If some rearrangement of duties within a department is necessary, I feel that the heads of departments will undertake to provide required services, particularly those required by the Auditor-General.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: APPOINTMENT OF MR BARNARD TO OFFICE OF AUSTRALIAN WAR GRAVES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it correct that Mr Lance Barnard, a former Deputy Prime Minister in the Whitlam Labor Government, has been appointed by this Government to the position of Director of the Office of Australian War Graves in Canberra? Has this reported appointment been criticised by some people as an example of jobs for the boys or has it been correctly seen as the appointment of a former senior parliamentarian with both experience and ability to a position of responsibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Young has drawn attention to this very important appointment in my Department of the Director of the Office of Australian War Graves. It is correct that Mr Barnard has been appointed to that position. It is true that Mr Barnard was Deputy Prime Minister in the Labor Government of which the Prime Minister was Mr Whitlam. It is also true that there has been very wide acceptance of the appointment of a very able person who served Australia as the Ambassador to Sweden and in other places, as well as holding the office of Deputy Prime Minister with distinction. Obviously we expect to see service of that kind offered in my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: I also indicate that as far as I am aware there has not been a great deal of criticism on the matter except from Senator Walsh. I noticed that he was reported as drawing attention to the jobs for the boys proposals in the Press at the same time as the announcement was made about Mr Barnard's appointment. I can only deprecate that viewpoint, and I am sorry that he sees it in that light. As I understand it, on the whole, the appointment has been well accepted in the community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Yesterday the Minister answered a question from Senator Cavanagh about Kakadu National Park in which he said that there was a desire to change the boundaries of the Park to allow mining of the Koongarra deposit to proceed, but that the Minister would like to consult further with the traditional owners and the Northern Land Council. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: It would be desirable . . . if the Government can move that way . . . with the agreement of the Aboriginal people . . .

How does the Minister reconcile this statement with his letter to the Northern Land Council, dated 28 April, which advised that the Federal Government had decided to excise a further area from the Kakadu National Park, in response to Denison, with no consultation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no question that either the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs or the Commonwealth Government is giving away any Aboriginal land or is excising Aboriginal land for a mining company in the Alligator Rivers Region in the Northern Territory. It is quite untrue. The statement released, I think recently, by traditional owners on this matter derives from their concern about the Government's intention to realign the Koongarra project area and to exclude that project area from the Kakadu National Park.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be understood that regardless of whether the project area is inside the National Park or excluded from the National Park it will remain Aboriginal land, and no mining can take place on it unless the proper consent procedures are followed and unless proper consent is obtained from the traditional owners. I think that is a central point: The status of the land as Aboriginal land is not under threat and is not in question. Moreover, no mining lease can be granted over the area until the Aboriginals have concluded an agreement with the mining company in accordance with the Aboriginal Land Rights Act. The honourable senator asked about the proposed realignment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the excision area.

—This is the realignment of the proposed excision area. That is correct. This is consistent with long-standing and publicly stated Government policy to exclude the project area, should mining be approved, from the National Park. This intention was made known by the Government in 1977 when it announced its decision to permit the mining of uranium following the Ranger inquiry. The net effect of the proposed realignment of the excision area would be to make it a smaller excision area, to make the area of the National Park greater and to exclude the escarpment completely from the proposed project area. It would in fact enable some environmentally important areas to be returned to the National Park.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator is quite correct; the next step is extensive consultation with the Northern Land Council and with traditional owners. In fact I really could not communicate where we want to start from until we have a Government decision as to what we wanted to propose. But I am scheduled to visit Darwin next Sunday and Monday and I propose to take that opportunity to meet representatives of the Northern Land Council and traditional owners of the Koongarra project area to talk about their concerns and, I hope, to clarify some of the issues which have been raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and I refer to Senator Walsh's intemperate attacks on former Government members who have been appointed to government positions. I suggest that Senator Walsh exercise some self control which he seems to be singularly unable to do. I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that prior to--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Why should Senator Sim use an introduction to a question to attack Senator Walsh? I think that was completely out of order and should have been ruled so.
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Sim.

—I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that, prior to 1973, former members of the Parliament holding government appointed positions were entitled to only half of the ordinary parliamentary superannuation entitlements? Is it a fact that in 1973 a committee headed by former Senator Willesee recommended-a recommendation that was accepted by the Government-that on the basis of equity such appointees should receive full superannuation entitlements? Are there former members of the Parliament, other than Government members, who hold government-appointed positions-I do not ask for their names-and who receive parliamentary superannuation? Are the Commonwealth provisions similar to those which Mr Wran, the Premier of New South Wales, is currently proposing to adopt in that State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of comments have been made on this subject. It ought to be said that the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act does provide that the retiring allowance payable to a former member shall be reduced by the amount of any salary or pension payable to that member as a result of service in a State parliament or in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, and it may be reduced at the discretion of the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust if the member is in receipt of another Commonwealth pension, other than a social security or repatriation pension. A provision requiring a retiring allowance to be reduced where the former member was in receipt of remuneration as the holder of an office under, or from employment by, the Commonwealth or a State, or an authority of the Commonwealth or a State, was removed from the Act by the Labor Government in 1973. I think that what has been said by Senator Sim accurately explains the way in which that operated.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Willesee, in his second reading speech of 31 May 1973, said that this change would bring the Act into line with the Superannuation Act and the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act, from which corresponding re-employment provisions were removed in 1965. I have seen in the Press a report to the effect that the Government of New South Wales is considering making changes to that State's parliamentary superannuation scheme, but I have no details of the proposed changes. However, the matter referred to by Senator Sim concerns the superannuation Act which, of course, applies to members of all parties. The payments that are made to any retired member are in accordance with the Act. Where necessary, the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust exercises its discretion and makes a decision. A number of distinguished former parliamentarians from both sides of the Parliament hold offices of profit under the Crown and have their parliamentary superannuation paid entirely in accordance with the Act.

—It is true that certain questions were asked in the Senate recently concerning new restrictions on certain items of cosmetic surgery which are not carried out pursuant to medical indications. I know of no reason why that question might have arisen. It might be appropriate to have it looked at to see whether there is any basis for the report that the honourable senator may have seen, but I can put no substance to it at all.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BELCONNEN MALL, AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: ISSUE OF STRATA TITLES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory been drawn to the request from the small shopkeepers at the Belconnen Mall that they be given the opportunity to purchase the shops that they occupy through the strata title mechanism? Will the Minister advise of his basic support or otherwise, for the proposition and, if approved, get the necessary preparations under way as soon as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information from the Minister for the Capital Territory on this matter and, if the Senate will bear with me, I will seek to put as much of it as I can on the record. The Minister is aware of the meeting held last night with regard to the Belconnen Mall. I understand that over 200 persons attended that meeting and that it was resolved that a request should be made for strata titles to be issued. I am further informed that a deputation from the Australian Association for Independent Businesses, representing in particular the Belconnen Traders Association, will be meeting the Minister for the Capital Territory today. I understand that the discussions will surround the proposals which came forward from last night's meeting. I also understand that the Minister, in implementing the Government's decision to sell the Belconnen Mall and to wind up the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, will be appointing a consultant from the private sector to advise and assist the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal posed in the question is most interesting. The Minister has informed me that he will be giving it most careful consideration, along with other proposals which no doubt will come before him. The Minister has also advised that whilst there is no legal obstacle to subdividing the complex under the Unit Titles Ordinance, it would be a most unusual course in this circumstance. Indeed, the Minister is informed that no major shopping centre anywhere in Australia currently operates under that method, although I understand that the practice has been adopted in some places overseas. The Minister wishes to give the assurance that the proposals forwarded by the Belconnen shopkeepers will be given most careful and detailed consideration.

In principle it can be stated that the concept of private ownership accords with this Government's philosophy and with the motivation behind the decision of the Government to release the Belconnen Mall to the private sector. The Minister understands that the deputation this afternoon will let him have a detailed written submission on the matter, and naturally he will have to take that into account in making final recommendations on the matter. The Minister also wanted me to note that the leader of the Australian Labor Party in the House of Assembly has already announced a firm commitment by the Labor Party, if elected, to buy back Belconnen Mall. That would create a fairly interesting situation if strata titles had been entered into. Finally, I should indicate that it is a matter of very detailed concern, but one which accords with the Government's philosophy. It certainly will be one which the Minister will be taking very seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy another question concerning the Tasmanian constitutional crisis which has been brought about by the refusal of the Legislative Council to accept the Lowe Government's compromise legislation on the Lower Gordon hydro-electric power scheme. Is the Minister aware that the Tasmanian Solicitor-General has advised the Legislative Council that it has no power to alter a money Bill such as the one involved but that the Council has ignored this advice? Does the Minister agree with the Melbourne Age editorial of 5 May which described the situation as one in which a small group of Liberal Party independents, elected by one of Australia's worst gerrymanders, is attempting to block the wishes of a democratically elected government on a major issue and is promising to do so indefinitely? In view of the Prime Minister's statement last month that the south-western wilderness of Tasmania is irreplaceable-his words-and in view of last week's decision by the Tasmanian Government to declare the gorges of the Franklin and Olga rivers a national park, will Federal finance now be forthcoming in line with the Prime Minister's promise of last June?

—A commitment was given in 1975 to assist the Tasmanian Government to establish a national park of world significance in the south-west to include a substantial wilderness area. The Commonwealth Government has already contributed $350,000 towards the cost of a resources survey in this area. Further commitment has been limited to an undertaking to consider requests in respect of specific proposals associated with the protection of the region when the resources survey is completed. The Prime Minister reaffirmed this in his letter to the Premier of Tasmania on 19 February this year. The final report of the resources survey is still awaited and the matter cannot appropriately be taken further until that stage is reached. I am not aware of the details of any advice the Tasmanian Solicitor-General may have provided on the question to which Senator Chipp refers. In any event, any constitutional issues arising from differences between the two Houses of the Tasmanian Parliament are State issues and not issues for the Commonwealth Government. I have not seen the Age editorial. I will direct my attention to it.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask my question with great respect. The general contents of my question were not unknown to the Minister. They fall within his area of responsibility. I particularly and specifically wanted to know: Will the Prime Minister or the Government now honour the promise made specifically by the Prime Minister in June to give significant financial assistance to the Tasmanian Government now that the area of the Franklin and Olga rivers has, in fact, been declared a national park by the Tasmanian Government? Can I have an answer to that specific question now or at some time in the near future?

—I directed my attention to what had happened up to date, that is, to the preliminary surveys and the amounts of money being made available. I am not informed as to what the Government's reaction would be following the recent action outlined by Senator Chipp. I will direct the Prime Minister's attention to that matter and seek a reply.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Education to the changes proposed by the Cabinet Review of Commonwealth Functions and their application to tertiary students. Will the Minister advise how the prospective loans to be introduced for tertiary students will be allocated? What length of time will be set for repayment of such a loan by the graduated student?

—The Government proposes that a loans scheme for tertiary students which would supplement assistance provided under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and related schemes will be introduced from the beginning of next year-1982. The Government's intention is that the scheme will be administered by tertiary institutions. At this stage it is not possible to provide details about the scheme as it is necessary to carry out negotiations with banks and tertiary institutions. The details of the loans scheme will be made public as soon as they have been finalised.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, relates to the recent report of approaches being made to the Federal Government by both the Western Australian and Northern Territory governments to build nuclear power stations. Can the Minister advise what was the exact nature of the approaches made by the Government of Western Australia and what was the response of the Federal Government? Have any agreements been made between the Federal Government and the Western Australian Government in relation to nuclear power stations? Have any feasibility studies been done by the Federal Government regarding construction in that State? As an official Northern Territory Government report rejected, on both economic and constitutional grounds, a proposal to construct a nuclear power station, will the Minister advise what those constitutional grounds were? In view of the controversy which surrounds the introduction of nuclear energy stations in Australia, will the Government instigate an inquiry to gauge the opinions and wishes of the Australian people on this important issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The general situation regarding electric power generation in Australia is that in most, if not all, States there is an abundant and relatively cheap supply of coal which provides an effective and inexpensive source of electric power generation. So the general question of alternative generation has not come up. I have read in the Press suggestions that the Western Australian Government was contemplating putting under study the construction of a nuclear power station. I have not had any formal approaches from the Western Australian Government.
—Mr Anthony has.

—I am not aware of any such approaches. Senator Coleman has interjected that Mr Anthony has. It would not be appropriate to make such an approach to Mr Anthony whose portfolio is that of Trade and Resources. I would have thought that in any case it would be made at the Prime Ministerial level. I am not aware of any such approaches but I will check to see whether any have been made. As I have said, I understand that there have been some informal considerations by the Western Australian Government in that regard. No agreements, arrangements or feasibility studies have been entered into by the Commonwealth Government. I am unaware whether the Western Australian Government has made any particular studies on the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The Northern Territory is faced with a considerable dilemma. It does not have a source of coal. It has a very antiquated power station which is making a very severe loss of the order of $50m or $60m a year. That is an intolerable burden on Australian taxpayers. The question is as to its replacement. The Territory does not have a coal supply close by. It has been examining a number of methods of alternative supply of energy. One proposal which the Commonwealth has assisted in considering has been that in co-partnership with Western Australia a hydro-electric scheme should be developed on the Ord River and there should be a sharing of power by means of a reticulation power line to the Northern Territory. I understand that experts say that such a scheme would be technically possible and economic. That proposal is still under practical consideration. The Northern Territory has been looking to see whether it could attract major industries to build up its base load of power. The size of a power station and its type of generation depend very much upon its base load. I understand that it has been unable to attract industries of the size of an alumina smelter or a similar kind of industry. Therefore a coal-based power station automatically pre-selects itself. There have been some reports in the Press that the Northern Territory Government has looked at the possibility of using nuclear energy. I have had no discussions in any formal way with the Government on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —'In any formal way'-what is the effect of the qualification?

—Senator Walsh asks why I put the qualification. The fact of the matter is that anybody who understands nuclear power would know that if we were to have a nuclear power station, in order to have economies of scale it would have to be a very large one indeed. That would be completely out of consideration in the Northern Territory context. The matter did not have any factual basis from the start. It would require enormous redevelopment of industry in the Northern Territory. There has been no discussion on the matter with me. There have been numerous and continuous discussions with my Department. I do not doubt that Northern Territory officers have raised with officers of my Department the feasibility of nuclear power generation. Indeed, there has been a running dialogue. But, taken in context, in the areas of Australia where we have cheap coal the use of coal for the generation of power would be immensely cheaper than the use of nuclear energy and there would be no necessity for more expensive or complex power generation. It is true that the availability of coal in Western Australia is limited basically to the Collie area. Nevertheless, natural gas is coming ashore. I know that there have been some discussions within Western Australia, but I do not know of any that are immediately current. Therefore, Senator Coleman's question has no basis in the broad consideration.

—I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister to indicate the constitutional grounds on which the report was rejected by the Northern Territory Government and whether, in view of the controversy which surrounds the implementation of nuclear energy, the Government would instigate an inquiry to gauge the opinions and wishes of the people.

—I am not aware of any constitutional grounds. It may well be that there has been some report in the Press on that matter. If the honourable senator so desires, I could inquire of the Northern Territory Government about this matter. I am unaware of any constitutional impediment to the construction of a nuclear power station in a State or self-governing Territory. There would be, of course, a responsibility to the Commonweath with regard to the Northern Territory. I am quite unaware of any impediments. There may be some. If so, I will acquaint--
—There would be under the Atomic Energy Act.

—It is true that the Atomic Energy Act, which we are in the process of looking at for purposes of reform, has defence powers, and it is just possible that there may be some qualifications there. I would not have thought that any court would uphold a defence power in these terms. However, it may. As to the question of holding an inquiry, since the matter has not arisen, the Commonwealth has not contemplated any such inquiry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, during its inquiry into quarantine some time ago, discovered that, contrary to advice received from the Department of Health, quarantine officers do not have the power to enter Aboriginal lands. Existing quarantine operations depend upon the goodwill of the various Aboriginal land councils. A very serious situation would exist if quarantine officers were impeded or prevented from undertaking control and eradication measures in the event of an exotic disease outbreak. In this respect, the Senate Committee recommended:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . that action be taken to amend either the Quarantine Act or the Aboriginal Lands Act to guarantee the legality of quarantine operations, while fully protecting the rights of the Aboriginal occupants of the land.
I ask: What progress has the Government made in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —An examination of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act is presently in progress. Honourable senators will recall that I brought the Rowland report into the Senate late last year. That report examined some of the practical difficulties which had arisen in the operation of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The Northern Territory Government and a number of other interested bodies had made representations in relation to the Act. I can advise the Senate that on 19 March this year I met in Darwin the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory, representatives of his Government, representatives of each of the land councils and Commonwealth officers, and we discussed possible changes to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The changes go far beyond the points which have been raised by Senator Thomas, but they do include those points.

ANSWER.PARA: It might be worth mentioning that, as a result of that meeting, a working party was established which involved representatives of the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments and of the land councils. That working party is examining specific issues and will report back to another full meeting of the ad hoc council, as it were, which will be meeting again in May. I intend to go back to the Northern Territory next Monday for a meeting of this group examining the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. One of the issues which was raised and which is being considered is the matter mentioned by Senator Thomas. It is seen as a potential difficulty and is one of the issues to which the representatives are addressing themselves. I hope it is one of the issues we will be able to resolve. I was encouraged by the evident good will displayed by all parties at the meeting held on 19 March. I hope that our discussions next week will lead to agreement on measures which could be undertaken to reduce any specific matters of concern in relation to the operation of what is a most important piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. How does he reconcile the razor gang recommendation No. 3 relating to the Department of Administrative Services to limit the functions of the Government Printer and the Australian Government Publishing Service to the barest minimum, with recommendation No. 6 under the Defence heading that all functions of the Defence printing establishment be transferred to the AGPS within 12 months? Will the Minister tell the Senate what the net effect of these changes will be on the Government Printer and the AGPS in respect of employment and financial savings and whether printing now normally carried out by the Government Printer in Australia will, in future, be carried out by the cheap labour countries to the north of Australia?

—I think all honourable senators will know that among the objectives of the whole Review of Commonwealth Functions were desires for a leaner, more efficient Federal Government and also for greater capacity for a federal government to be able to make tax cuts available to its citizens. The honourable senator asks about changes which have been proposed within the Department of Administrative Services in relation to two of its agencies. I understand that the proposals for the AGPS will not reduce the service available to the public. In regard to the particular matters that the honourable senator has raised and which require specific information, I will undertake to seek that information for him.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The honourable senator has answered neither of my questions. I asked: What will be the financial and employment aspects of these changes? The second part of my question was: Will the publishing activities of the Government Printer, now carried out in Australia, be carried out in cheap labour countries to the north of Australia? He has answered neither of those questions.

—I thought that I had answered those questions quite clearly by indicating that any detailed response, that would be worth something, in relation to the financial or employment aspects and any response on where printing might take place in the future, was properly a matter to be referred to my colleague.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I preface it by saying that now the Government has decided to insist that people who come from New Zealand have passports, it is topical to ask a question relating to people who come from New Zealand and the social security benefits that they get in this country. Is it true that someone who receives unemployment benefit in New Zealand immediately prior to coming to Australia, is immediately able to claim Australian unemployment benefit? If so, why should a New Zealander get this benefit without waiting the qualifying period that would apply to Australians?

—There is an agreement between Australia and New Zealand with respect to the payment of social security payments in each country regarding the nationals of the other country, as there is an agreement between Australia and the United Kingdom. Broadly the position for New Zealanders in this country is the same as that which applies to Australians in New Zealand, that is, if they reside in the other country then they have a general entitlement to the social security benefits of that country. I was not aware that the terms of that agreement extended to ensuring that a waiting period served in the one country qualified a person for a benefit in the other country. That appears to be the position put by Senator Townley in his question. It is a matter which I will examine but if the facts are as he has indicated then I assume that the agreement provides a continuous right to the various forms of benefit and that a waiting period in one country is equivalent to the waiting period in another.

—Mr President, I ask a very brief supplementary question. When the Minister is replying, will he pay some attention to whether the New Zealand payments are the same amount as the Australian payments or whether they are in fact, as I am informed, only about half of what recipients in Australia would get?

—I can inform the honourable senator that there is no parity between the payments. Coincidentally, there may be payments which are the same, but in general the two countries do not seek to have equal levels of benefit in any area.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I ask the Minister to imagine the situation whereby an uninsured person, believing himself or herself to be 'disadvantaged', arrives for urgent treatment at a doctor's surgery or a hospital and in so doing is acting upon Senator Chaney's offer to be treated in advance of receiving a 'disadvantaged' card. Can the Minister assure this person, if it is later found that he or she does not meet the official criteria, that hospital or medical charges will not be charged to him or her? I further ask the Minister whether he can explain what the criteria will be for casual workers who cannot possibly know their total income until the end of the financial year.

—The proposals for the definition of 'disadvantaged' have been drawn clearly to make sure they are generous and that they pick up all those people who reasonably will need to be covered under that heading. If there is an uninsured person who believes himself or herself to be disadvantaged, and that person is within that definition, then there will be no problem. If that person is not within that definition that person should properly be carrying his or her own health insurance cover.
—Or paying.

—Or paying his or her own medical bills, as my colleague interjects. The detailed administrative arrangements which will come into force, I think from 1 September, in relation to these matters are at present being worked out by consultation between the departments, and I imagine they will be made known publicly as soon as possible to pick up some of the cases at the margin such as the honourable senator raised in the second part of his question.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In view of the recent rapid moves to correct anomalies in the superannuation scheme covering members of Federal Parliament, will the Government now urgently and sympathetically reconsider the 1972 report and recommendations of the Jess committee concerning the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act in the interests of correcting the anomalies which have for many years disadvantaged some 7,000 ex-servicemen and between 30 and 40 widows of ex-servicemen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Jess committee report was dealt with some eight years ago and the recommendations were incorporated into legislation with the introduction of the current Defence Forces Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme which took effect on 1 October 1972. It is a principle that beneficiaries under government-sponsored superannuation schemes are paid on retirement the benefits for which they have contributed in accordance with the rules of the scheme applying to them at that time. Since the commencement of the new DFRDB Scheme annual pension increases have been granted to former Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Scheme pensioners, that is, those who retired before October 1972. I presume that is the group to which Senator Bjelke-Petersen is referring. So they have had increases since then and the pensions payable have more than doubled during that time.

ANSWER.PARA: I will refer the question for further consideration to the Minister for Defence, but it might be helpful if Senator Bjelke-Petersen could indicate just what are the specific matters she has raised. I think the Government is familiar in general terms with the complaints this group of people has, but as I have said they have had increases under the old scheme. The pensions have certainly doubled. But there may be other complaints which Senator Bjelke-Petersen would like us to investigate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate following the answer that he gave yesterday to Senator Gietzelt about the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport at Mascot. Did he say yesterday that the Major Airport Needs of Sydney study recommended that the solution to Sydney's airport problems is the construction of a close-spaced parallel runway at Mascot airport and the Commonwealth Government believes this to be the only short term solution? Is the Minister aware that in the last annual report to this Parliament by the Commonwealth Department of Transport it was stated that New South Wales members of the MANS study did not feel able to agree to a joint report to governments and dissociated themselves from the recommendations and report by the Commonwealth members? In fact, the State members disagreed with the Commonwealth's recommendations. Is the Minister now saying that the New South Wales Government should ignore the recommendations of its own officers, all of whom come from New South Wales, and blindly follow the recommendations of the Commonwealth officers? When the Minister says that the Commonwealth Government believes that the construction of a close-spaced parallel runway at Mascot is the only short term solution to the immediate airport needs of Sydney, has there in fact been a Cabinet decision on the matter or is he merely expressing a personal opinion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the last question first. All studies have indicated two quite separate things. The first is that in the long term there is a need for a second international airport to serve Sydney and New South Wales. All studies have indicated that the lead time for producing such an airport will be from 12 to 20 years. That is a matter of fact and not one of opinion. Secondly, all studies have revealed that the present Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport cannot survive the next 12 to 20 years with the present or proposed traffic. It cannot cope. Quite apart from a second airport site, something must be done to deal with Sydney's immediate problems for the next decade or so. They are facts.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also a fact, accepted by all, that there are no alternative airfields which at present could function in the place of Mascot. For example, Bankstown airport already has its disabilities. So we rest on two facts. The first is that there is need to locate a site and to start preparing for a period several decades ahead. The second fact is that there is need to determine how the city of Sydney and New South Wales will meet their needs for the next decade.

It is true that the MANS committee was a Joint Commonwealth-State committee and that prior to reaching its final conclusions the State officials withdrew on the instructions of their Government. It is true also that the Commonwealth officers on that committee recommended that there be a close-spaced parallel runway. I presume that the withdrawal of the State officials signifies that they did not support that proposal. So that is factual. But what I want to make perfectly clear is that the New South Wales Government has at least as much responsibility as the Commonwealth Government to determine what is to be the solution for Sydney and New South Wales for the next decade or two decades and it has done nothing to indicate what that solution should be. It is no solution at all to point to an area like Bringelly or elsewhere and say: 'In 20 years time we will have an international airport'. What I said yesterday-I repeat it now-is that we are already denying the people of Sydney valuable work and valuable tourist ingress by the fact that because of this impasse we now have to deflect international airline flights to Brisbane and Melbourne. That will continue. We are facing an incapacity to deal with wide-bodied jets. Far more importantly, unless the State Government is willing to face up to the matter, the commuter airlines from all country districts will face a limitation and an ultimate near or total exclusion. The real fact of the matter is that the State has not put up any solution whatsoever of the problem in the next decade or two decades. It is no solution at all to talk about a second international airport. The only solution which has been put up is the close-spaced parallel runway. There is no other solution. That is the one which the Commonwealth is advocating that the State now support so that it can get on with the job to see that Sydney is not further deprived and that the country people of New South Wales are not denied their commuter services.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES GOVERNMENT: FUNDING OF POLITICAL ADVERTISING CAMPAIGN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that millions of dollars of Federal funds allocated to New South Wales are to be used by the Government of that State to subsidise the Australian Labor Party's political advertising campaign at the forthcoming State election? Does the Minister agree that this is a gross misuse of taxpayers' money? Does it represent a perverse sense of priorities of the New South Wales Government at a time when that Government claims that it has insufficient funds to meet its proper governmental responsibilities?

—It is true that the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales is proposing to legislate to provide that the funding of party political campaigns in elections shall be borne quite heavily by the taxpayer.
—The fact is that parties other than the Labor Party have rejected this as being an unwanted, unwarranted--
—Your party has not. You do it with taxpayers' money. You have your fingers in the till. It is taxpayers' money.
—The interjections serve only to emphasise the point. The fact is that the Labor Party proposes to use taxpayers' money to--
—The fact is that you have your fingers in the till here.

—There is an intention that I should react to the statement by the Leader of the Opposition: 'You have got your fingers in the till here'. Mr President, in case you have not heard it, he has said it five times with the intention that you and I should hear it.
—I have.
—I am not asking you to react. It is meant to be utterly offensive. I presume that what he is trying to say is that the Government's advertising expenditure today is using taxpayers' money.
—At the last election it did.

—If that is the intention, I want to say that the Labor Party, over past years, had not only its fingers but also its fists heavily into the till because its expenditure, using the advertising facilities of government, was far greater than ours.
—The Government Information Unit uses taxpayers' money.
—If indeed Senator Button is saying that what we are doing is wrong and is confessing that what they were doing was more wrong, let him say so.
—That makes it right, does it, for you to have your fingers in the till? We are saying it openly-not under the table, not with fingers in the till.

—With the assistance of the interjections, I will repeat to the people of Australia that the Labor Party in New South Wales is saying, as it said at the Premiers Conference, that it has no money to finance hospitals, schools, roads and bridges but that it will provide money for its own advertising campaigns for the State election. There cannot be greater hypocrisy than a Premier saying: 'I do not have the money to do essential things for the people of Australia but I have the money to finance Labor Party advertising in a State election campaign.' Nothing could be more hypocritical.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. I refer to the Government's decision to cease regular collection and publication of Commonwealth Employment Service statistics of the unemployed and of unfilled vacancies. Does this mean that the level of unemployment in individual cities and towns within a State will no longer be publicly available? Can the reviews of the Australian Bureau of Statistics be structured in such a way that they can show variations in the level of unemployment within a State? If they cannot, does this indicate that the Government is not interested in determining to what extent there are different levels of unemployment within a State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — If I could take first the last part of the question, the Government is intent on discovering unemployment levels and the resources of the Commonwealth Employment Service throughout Australia are provided to assist people to obtain employment that is available to them. Details concerning the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and the information that can flow from its figures, I must seek from the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. With regard to the announcement that the Government is to discontinue the gathering of Commonwealth Employment Service statistics, it is known that Australian Bureau of Statistics information is provided. I understand that the Minister is able also to make available other information with regard to employment patterns throughout Australia. I will seek from the Minister information as to precisely what he is now able to make available and provide that to Senator Colston.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a report released by Amnesty International on 28 April which looks at claims of widespread torture of political prisoners in Iraq. Will the Minister comment on this report and, in particular, the documented case histories of 15 former Iraqi prisoners who were subjected to beatings, electrical shock, sexual abuse and other tortures while they were detained in prison by the ruling Ba'ath Party? Does the Minister agree that the treatment allegedly given to these prisoners during their detention was cruel, inhuman and in complete violation of the United Nations standard minimum rules for the treatment of prisoners? If so, in accordance with the Government's concern for human rights, will the Minister urge the Government: Firstly, to call on Iraq to honour its commitments under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which it ratified in 1971 and which prohibits torture; secondly, to support Amnesty International strongly both in its plea to President Hussein to issue a clear ban on torture and in its recommendation for concrete measures to protect prisoners, including an end to incommunicado detention-allowing lawyers, family and doctors prompt access to prisoners-and bringing people to court promptly after arrest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government has noted Press reports of an Amnesty International report containing allegations of torture of political prisoners in Iraq. The Government views with concern such allegations which, if substantiated, would represent violations of obligations under several articles of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. However, before considering whether any approach to Iraq would be appropriate, the Government would wish to establish with greater certainty the grounds for the allegations which have been made in the report. In that connection the Government will seek a copy of the Amnesty International report. The Government is firmly committed to the taking of international action to eliminate the practice of torture and the ill-treatment of prisoners generally. In seeking this objective we acknowledge the important role to be played in the non-government sphere by organisations such as Amnesty International. The Government will continue to focus its energies on seeking progress through bodies such as the United Nations Commission on Human Rights which, as honourable senators may know, is currently engaged, amongst other things, in drafting a convention against torture. I will seek information on the more detailed aspects raised by Senator Missen.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WAGE FIXING AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS SYSTEMS: PROPOSED INQUIRY

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, by stating that I understand that a Federal-State inquiry is to be conducted into Australia's wage fixing and industrial relations systems, as suggested by the Premier of Western Australia, Sir Charles Court, and that, amongst other things, the inquiry will report on the economic implications of the 35-hour week and the level and effect of industrial disputes. Can the Minister say whether the same inquiry is prepared to take into account the effect of industrial accidents on the economy and, more importantly, on those in the community affected by the lack of proper and uniform safety standards? I point out that industrial accidents are responsible for about three times more lost time in industry than industrial disputes.

—I do not have a great deal of detail about the proposed Federal-State inquiry raised by the honourable senator in his question. The matter is one in which there may be some concern about some of the factors he has raised-the 35-hour week and industrial disputes, both of which touch upon the ability of industry to pay wages. I agree with him that the question of industrial accidents is also relevant to the profitability of industry and to the extent to which higher wages can be paid. Therefore, I will draw the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations to the point which has been made by the honourable senator so that, if a range of factors of that sort is to be examined, the question of industrial accidents can also be considered.
—I ask that further questions be placed on notice.
—I object to that.
—There was no light flashing. You are trying to crib, Senator.
—On the contrary, the light had gone out when I rose. It was a full hour. If anyone feels aggrieved, I am perfectly happy to take another question.

—I am aggrieved. I have been invited, if I am aggrieved, to make my point. I have endeavoured to interrupt the flow of important matters in this place by rising to my feet. I do not know the formula to be followed, but I would have thought I might have got the call. I was rising to my feet to ask a question concerning Bobby Sands. I now seek leave to ask that question.
—Whilst the full hour had gone by and I rose at the normal and conventional time, I am perfectly happy to invite the honourable senator to ask a question.
—Question Time is entirely in the Minister's hands. I call Senator Georges.

—It is astonishing to me that we should go through the whole of Question Time without any statement by the Government concerning Bobby Sands. I now ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: What message of concern has the Government sent to the British Government and Prime Minister? If it has not sent a message, why not? Is the death of Bobby Sands of no significance in this place? If it is of no significance, will the Leader of the Government say so?
—He was a murderer.
—Did the honourable senator say that he was a murderer? I put it to the honourable senator that I am neither Irish nor Catholic. I have no subjective interest in this case.
—Order! Senator, do not debate the issue. You have to ask the question which the Minister has agreed to take.

—The interjection from the other side was that he was a murderer. If we look at Bobby Sands' background and the harassment which he faced, which forced him into his position and eventually led to his imprisonment and human sacrifice--
—Order! Please ask your question.
—Then the word 'murderer' ought to be thrust back down the neck of the honourable senator who interjected in that way.
—Order! Senator, you are debating the question. Put your question.
—I have asked the question. I now ask the Leader of the Government: What statement of concern is he prepared to make?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several days ago, I think in response to Senator Georges, I outlined the situation regarding Bobby Sands. I think it does not help at all to cause a controversy on the matter. The fact is that the problems of Northern Ireland are both complex and tragic and, as the Prime Minister said on 29 April, they are properly the responsibility of the United Kingdom Government. There has been some question about the status of Bobby Sands as a prisoner. He was not a political prisoner as such. In the past, Bobby Sands had been convicted for an offence of armed robbery and had served a sentence for that. He was subsequently convicted of being in possession of weapons and was serving a gaol sentence. Nobody looks with anything other than great sadness on the fact that he chose to take his own life. Nobody looks with anything but utter misery on the plight of that torn apart country of Northern Ireland today. But it does not help for us to add to that.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the man, in the ordinary processes of law-I think no one disputes that they were the ordinary processes of law-was convicted and was in gaol. The fact is that the man, while in gaol, elected not to take nourishment and to face the inevitable consequence of that by surrendering his own life. That was a choice that he chose to make. It could have been rectified at any time. He sought to do that and he has done that. I suggest that what we should do is direct our attentions to how we can help to resolve the overall problem of a country which, for some hundreds of years, has been torn apart by civil war and internal fighting. Everybody regards this as ugly and horrible. I would not want to say a single thing that would exacerbate that problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April Senator Button asked me a question concerning foreign aid. I undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to seek his reply. The Minister, to whom the first person pronouns apply, has replied as follows: On 28 April Senator Button asked for information concerning the level of Australia's overseas aid. I wish to assure the honourable senator that the Government remains committed to achieving the target set by the United Nations General Assembly for developed countries to contribute 0.7 per cent each year of their gross national product towards official development assistance for less developed countries. At the United Nations General Assembly in 1980 Australia undertook to make its best efforts to reach the target by 1990 and continues to maintain this position. As the honourable senator indicated, Australia's ODA for 1980-81 amounts to about 0.43 per cent of forecast GNP. This is the same percentage as that recorded in the previous year and at $553m represents an overall increase of 10.6 per cent over net expenditure last financial year. At this stage it is not appropriate for me to comment on the future level of funding of the overseas aid program which will be considered in the next Budget context.

—Last week Senator Evans asked me a question concerning some details of health insurance under the altered arrangements. I indicated some details then but said I would check my facts. The facts are as I gave them to him. There has been no change in the existing arrangements for the tax rebateability of direct health expenditure. This is quite separate from the decision to give rebateability for premiums paid for basic hospital and medical insurance. Where uninsured persons incur health costs or where insured persons incur costs not covered by benefits, the amounts involved will be included within the general rebate of $1,590 as at present.
—So you don't get any benefit from them until you have scored $1,590 in toto.

—There has been no change in the arrangements and I would say that only a small percentage of taxpayers exceed the $1,590 block, exactly as the honourable senator indicates. The thrust of the Government's decision is to encourage people back to health insurance. On this basis the decision was made that the concessional rebate arrangement of 32c in the dollar outside the $1,590 block would apply to premiums for basic hospital and medical insurance. So two kinds of rebateability are available-one for everyone in terms of basic hospital and medical insurance and one for those who have net expenses. Of course, that is as it has always been for amounts over and above the $1,590 block.

—I point out to honourable senators that today only 20 questions were asked during Question Time. The one asked by Senator Georges followed those 20. Of those 20, 17 were from honourable senators who did not ask a question yesterday. Today at the close of Question Time four honourable senators were eagerly seeking the call-Senator Primmer, Senator Georges, Senator Wheeldon and Senator Martyr. I repeat that only 20 questions were able to be asked. I again emphasise the need for questions to be couched in brief terms and to be to the point and, similarly, for answers to give information on the points raised so that more questions than at present can be asked during Question Time. We had 20 questions today and 25 questions yesterday. I also must make reference to insult by innuendo, implication or reflection. I cannot hear all things said in this chamber, but it is not conducive to the smooth and flowing conduct of this place to have imputations which give offence to others.

—by leave-I merely wish to raise for consideration of honourable senators a matter of which no doubt they are all aware but which we might reconsider. I refer to the system used in some foreign parliaments whereby some kind of mechanism is provided for honourable senators who wish to ask a question. I gather it is quite a small piece of electronics and easy to devise in this modern age. You, sir, would have before you an electronic indicator to allow you at all times to know which senators sought the call and the order in which they had sought it. I wonder whether we can consider that system, which would end the ritual of honourable senators leaping up and down regularly right throughout Question Time day after day. That may be extremely good exercise for their skiing and things like that, but I suggest that in this day and age it is an undignified and childish practice.

—The matter of Question Time has been considered over many years at many meetings of the Standing Orders Committee. I believe that keeping a record of questions asked by honourable senators and making an endeavour to permit questions the following day from those who did not ask a question the previous day ensures, over a period, the most equitable and fairest method. There is no facility to allow an individual senator to ask a question of urgency but we are doing our best to improve the situation.

—by leave-Mr President, if, by implication, I was critical of the method you use, I had reason. Perhaps I did ask a question yesterday-I am not quite certain-but over the past few weeks I have been somewhat inactive at Question Time. Perhaps some would prefer me to remain inactive. However, I would have thought that one question, or even two questions, in the past six or seven weeks would have entitled me to a question today. That was the implication I was making when I was critical of your formula. We should look in greater depth at the number of questions which honourable senators have asked. If for some reason an honourable senator has been absent from this place and has not had an opportunity to ask a question over a period, surely he should not be deprived immediately of the opportunity to ask a question on the basis of one question asked previously in the week.
