SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Leader of the Opposition) (3.44)-Mr President, as I understand it, the Senate was to debate three issues today. Whatever procedures have been announced, I intend to do so. They are the Government's health statement, the statement on taxation and the statement on the ministerial Review of Commonwealth Functions which was carried out by the so-called razor gang. As far as the Opposition is concerned, these three statements illustrate the essential style of the Fraser Government. I characterise that essential style as muddled, incompetent, dishonest and destroying the political integrity and trust in the political system. There has been a charade of broken promises. The other feature which one can add to the description of 'muddled, incompetent and dishonest' is that the Government is stoned out of its collective mind with crude ideology. I wish to illustrate those points. They are quite substantial points-I ask Senator Walters who is trying to interject to bear the pain of waiting for a minute-which are easily illustrated in the context of the three statemens which are now before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, let me turn to the question of health. When I use the expression 'integrity in government', I think that all honourable senators will recall the promise of the Fraser Government to maintain Medibank. This is the fifth attempt by the Fraser Government to dishonour that promise to maintain Medibank. It is muddled, incompetent, and dishonest. It is also the fifth attempt to dishonour that promise. It means increased health charges for the ordinary citizen of Australia. It means that, far from the promised freedom of choice which the Fraser Government offers, the citizens of Australia will be conscripted into private health funds and have no choice in relation to that matter. It means an inevitable increase in the size of the Australian bureacracy-in the Department of Social Security-or total inefficiency in the assessment of the disadvantaged under the new proposals. It also means that it is not the final attempt to dishonour the promise in relation to Medibank, because it will have to be done again.

That is justified in terms of the slogan 'the user pays', as if the users of health care services were in exactly the same category as people choosing a motor car, be it a Jaguar, a Holden or whatever their choice might be. That is not so in relation to any mortal who cannot determine what his health situation is going to be. It is a proposal which, again, illustrates incompetence in the fact that it was being changed up to an hour before it was given in the House of Representatives last week by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar).

Secondly, there is the statement on taxation which illustrates the same points and in which Senator Walters, having exhibited a bit of bravado at the beginning of my remarks, has now lost interest. The statement on taxation also flows from the breaking of a promise which was made by the Fraser Government in 1975, accompanied by the brave rhetorical explanation that in the view of the Government tax indexation was necessary to keep governments honest. That promise was half honoured two years later. It has now been abandoned completely. Five years later honesty is the last thing that the Fraser Government wants as a criterion for its activities. Again, the news of that undertaking to abandon tax indexation did not get to the back bench of the Government parties until a few hours before it was given, if at all. This is another feature of the Fraser Government's style. Years ago Andrew Peacock used to have a club called the mushroom club. The whole of the Liberal Party is now a mushroom club. It is kept in the dark and fed on Fraser rhetoric. The Standing Orders prevent me from using another word which every honourable senator knows. It is a fact that the party is kept in the dark by the Fraser Government and fed on fresh bursts of ideology from time to time.

I turn now to the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the so-called razor gang. The report of the so-called razor gang is one which is full of sound and fury. It signifies very little except the flowering of Fraser Government ideology. It also represents, in a sense, a mad experiment in social engineering in which the Australian people are the guinea pigs designated for vivisection by this Government. It reminds me of the early horror films in which a deranged and deregistered doctor performed operations on innocent victims in the hope of creating some perfect human being and ended up creating a Frankenstein monster. The Cabinet of Malcolm Fraser is the Cabinet of Dr Calligari of the early horror films. The Fraser Government is experimenting in a social sense with an ideology which is totally unproven and which has no basic rationale, other than a series of slogans.

Let me not be misunderstood. I am not for a moment saying that it is not appropriate to have a review of Commonwealth Government functions. Of course it is appropriate to have such a review. I am not saying that institutions of the Commonwealth Government and past practices of the Commonwealth Government are in any sense sacrosanct. They are not. They should be subject to regular and sensible examination. I am merely saying that the latest activity-the razor gang's report-displays incompetence and muddling, and does not direct itself to the essential questions of good government. How could it direct itself to the essential questions of good government if the rationale for it is a series of unproven cliches and unproven slogans? It is said that the private sector will take up the slack. Will it do that as an act of faith? It is said that there will be more elbow room for the private sector as a result of the razor gang's deliberations. Another slogan used by the razor gang is that the user will pay. How much will the user pay? We will look at that in a moment. How much will the user pay in terms of export incentives given to companies as deductions and so on? Will the user pay only in respect of health services? As an experiment in government, the notion of the razor gang is absurd. It is advocating across the board cuts in the Public Service. That is a matter of rhetoric and ideology. What the razor gang has not done, and this is where the incompetence arises, has been to look at the functions of government in particular circumstances-for example, the returning to the States or private enterprise of the functions of government as an act of faith, not as a rational explanation of what the Government is about in terms of policy and decision-making.

Let me illustrate the point I am making by reference to education. The education services which a community provides are a function of education philosophy and education policy. They are not and should not be susceptible to crude ideology across the board. If, as the razor gang says, there is to be a further restriction on the eligibility of students to obtain tertiary education assistance, any decision on that should be about access to tertiary education. It is not a decision to be dealt with in a crude way by the so-called razor gang. It involves important questions of social policy. The same applies to the colleges of advanced education which it is said will be abolished. We all know that none of them will really be abolished. The question involved in restricting eligibility for the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme is a question which relates to access to education. It is a matter which will determine the future shape and quality of the society in which we live. It should not be determined by a group of political stuntmen, as the razor gang is. It should have been determined as a matter of Government education policy, not as a question of Fraser Government stunts.

Let us look at the areas of productivity, innovation, technological assessment and transfer. Properly handled, they are very important and vital functions of government in a modern economy. Indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) thought so himself a few years ago. In relation to these matters of productivity, innovation, technological transfer, in answer to a question in the House of Representatives on 9 November 1976, the Prime Minister said:
. . . the problems relating to productivity, management, labour and new technologies are matters that have always been there. They are long-term issues; they do not go away.

They went away last week as far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned. In the razor gang's report there were very significant cuts and a winding down of government initiatives in relation to all these matters, as a stunt in preparation for the next election. The Prime Minister was right when he said that in 1976. I am not a person who takes a biased or one-eyed view of the Prime Minister. He is sometimes right and he was right in 1976 when he said:
They are long-term issues; they do not go away.

Of course what has happened with this report is that the long-term issues are no longer being considered. As with education, productivity and technology, they are no longer being considered. This Government thinks no further than the next election and that is bad government.

I next look at the Commonwealth Employment Service. As a result of the abolition of CES statistics announced by the razor gang, a detailed breakdown of employment figures in the regions will no longer be available. That means that if we want to get detailed employment figures for places such as the Hunter Valley, Gladstone, the Latrobe Valley or Ballarat they will not be obtainable. Are these figures no longer important to this Government? Maybe it is very important to it not to have the unemployment figures for those places, but is it no longer important to the Government not to know the detailed breakdown of employment figures in those regions? If it is important, as this Government says, that the resources boom be handled properly, is it not vital to know the employment pattern in particular areas in Australia? Is it not vitally important to good government, as distinct from mad ideological government in the hands of a bunch of hillbillies meeting here in Parliament House?

The same thing can be said about the research functions of the Commonwealth Government which have been consistently wound down and are now being wound down further. These functions relate to the future of Australia and, of course, do not relate to the next election. That is why they have been wound down. But the future of Australia is more important than the next election and returning Malcolm Fraser to government at that election. That is what this document is about. All these things are examples of bad decision-making and lack of understanding of the function of government. It is the functions of government which have not been looked at by the so-called razor gang.

I refer to some of the decisions of this Government revealed by the razor gang to be wasteful, incompetent and/or dishonest. I will give some examples. I refer to the Broadcasting Information Service. A big sum of money is not involved but let us look at the history of that institution. It was a 1977 election promise of the Fraser Government to establish the Broadcasting Information Service. The Government had a mandate to establish that Service, but it did not have a mandate for anything which is in this report. A year ago it established the Broadcasting Information Service and appointed Mr Ian Fairweather at a salary of $30,000 a year to run that Service. For 12 months Mr Ian Fairweather was given nothing to do. He sat on his block-if honourable senators will pardon the colloquialism-earnt $30,000 and last week his job was abolished. Is that an example of competent government? Is that an example of careful government? I refer to other examples which are equally as bad. Only a month ago-this relates to questions of function in which Senator Walters will be interested-the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) opened the new building for the Australian Curriculum Development Centre in Canberra. I will quote from his speech given at the grand opening and launching of the Curriculum Development Centre. He said:
In the five years since its establishment the Curriculum Development Centre has undertaken a formidable array of projects which have resulted in an enrichment of the fabric of Australian education.

The whole speech was like that but that is one passage that I picked out. That speech was made on 18 March. Five weeks later the Curriculum Development Centre, whose new building was opened by the Minister with all those glorious expressions of what a great thing it was, was abolished. What did that little exercise cost the taxpayers of Australia? What did that new building and all the activities associated with its opening cost the peope of Australia? Is that good government? Is it not the function of the Minister for Education to determine what shall be done about these issues, or is it the function of the razor government? Of course the Minister for Education is a mouse compared with the razor gang, the heavies, who carry out all these silly decisions. I refer to the decision not to proceed with the electrification of the Sydney-Melbourne railway line. The razor gang says that it is not to proceed as it is not a worthwhile project. I refer to what the Prime Minister said last year about the electrification of the Sydney-Melbourne railway line. I will quote from his electorate talk given on 29 June 1980. He said:
The Commonwealth has also offered to fund half the cost of electrifying the Sydney-Melbourne railway line.
A couple of paragraphs on he said:

All these projects are a dramatic illustration of our commitment to Australia's national development, and of our desire to channel Government spending into directions that will build the basic strength of Australia.

In June 1980 the Prime Minister of this country made a virtue out of electrification of the Sydney-Melboure railway line. What happened to him was that the States said that it was a silly, wasteful program and knocked it back. Ten days ago, the Prime Minister makes a virtue out of changing that decision. Where now is the commitment to develop Australia's national institutions and to channel government expenditure to build the basic strength of Australia? Is that to be abandoned too? This is a now you see it, now you don't aspect of Fraser Government policy. It is a great sleight of hand. The Government produced the electrification of the railway line before the election, said what a good thing it was and made a virtue of that, but after the election it abolished it and said what a great thing that was. Now you see it, now you don't.

I will refer to some other quite silly things which have been done. I single out the area of communications. All these matters to which I am referring are designed basically to illustrate incompetence and that is what the razor gang report is. It is an incompetent document. The razor gang is a group of Ministers pulling not only the Parliament by the nose but also all honourable senators on the Government side. They have not read the review closely. They are so hepped up and steamed up with rhetoric. I refer to the communications decisions of the razor gang report. The decision of the Government on the Australian Broadcasting Commission is that there is scope for rationalisation of existing ABC locations. That sounds pretty important. It seems as though the Government will save a lot of money and that sounds very good. For the last three years the report of the Australian Broadcasting Commission to this Parliament and this Government has said: 'We want to rationalise our building facilities, but we do not have enough money to do it. Will you give us money to let us rationalise our building facilities?' The big razor gang came along and said: 'You have to rationalise your building facilities. Are we not a thoughtful group of good housekeepers in telling you what to do?' For three years the Commission has asked the Government to do that. Did the razor gang know nothing about that? Did it not consult with the ABC about that, or did it make this decision as do so many others-off the top of their silly heads? Secondly the Broadcasting Information Service, to which I have already referred, was created, a salary was paid to a man who was given nothing to do and then it was abolished. The Australia Post Courier Service, grandiosely says the razor gang, will be abolished and replaced by another body called something else.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not read it either.

—I have it in front of me. The honourable senator should not pick on me because I did not have my glasses on. That is unkind of the honourable senator with his natural generosity. The Australia Post Courier Service will be abolished. If honourable senators examine that they will see that what it really means is that the vans will be repainted. At what cost will this be to the Australian taxpayer? It will be called something else and basically it will carry out the same functions. It is described by the razor gang as some sort of government economy and saving. All that will happen is that the vans will be repainted at great cost. No doubt the work will go to the private sector so everybody will be all right. Rolf Harris or somebody will do it. The next decision of the razor gang relates to Telecom Australia. An inquiry into the functions of Telecom will be set up. Of course that inquiry is a sham in the context in which it is being announced. It is a sham because this Government has already stated its views about Telecom and they are pretty clear. I will indicate briefly the nature of those decisions which have been made about Telecom. The decision to set up an inquiry into Telecom is justified by the ideological, hobgoblin stuff of user payers. Let us look at the user pay principle in respect of Telecom. It is the only enterprise in Australia which has not increased its charges since 1975. No business in the private sector of the community can say that. Anybody who is listening to this debate will know that there is no business from the corner store to the great emporium that has not increased charges since 1975, other than Telecom. Telecom employs a lot of people and it is a profitable organisation. So the beady eyes of the private enterprise entrepeneurs fix on Telecom. The entrepreneurs say: 'Bits of that are pretty profitable. We ought to have that because we are interested in profits'. That is a legitimate activity, I suppose, for those people to engage in. But let me deal with the justification for this inquiry, that is, the ideology of user payers.

SPEECH.PARA: The profitable sector of the work done by Telecom subsidises the unprofitable sector, namely, the development of the country telephone network. It did so to the extent of $218m last year. Will honourable senators opposite go into the country electorates and say to the people-'We are selling the profitable part of Telecom because we believe in private enterprise and we are going to put your telephone services to tender for public enterprise'? The people out in the bush know that nobody interested in profits will buy that part of the telephone service. What is the Government really saying about that? It is saying that the profitable sector of Telecom can be taken away from it and given to its friends in private enterprise and that the taxpayers can pay for the country networks from now on. Is that the intention?

I am intrigued to see that post offices are to become organisations for the distribution of Government information brochures. Does not the Government have enough organisations working for it already at taxpayers expense trying to explain silly decisions like the decisions of the razor gang? I would have thought so. It has the Government Information Unit and all these other bodies such as Project Australia already working for it. Why does the Government want the poor post offices to distribute information to try to explain its policies? What will this cost? The razor gang does not tell us how much it will cost. I refer to other gobblydegook such as the decision that the High Court of Australia is to continue to have its reports published by private enterprise. It has been doing that for donkey's years. What is new about that? Another decision is that the Darwin university will not now be built; an eminently sensible decision, if I might say so. But there was never any commitment to build Darwin university. What is the Government doing by cluttering up the report with that sort of thing? That just adds additional costs for the Government Printer.

Apart from these silly sorts of expenditure cuts which illustrate imcompetence and bad government, a whole lot of extravagances which have been maintained are private extravagances of the Prime Minister. Andrew Peacock put his finger on this 10 or 14 days ago when he said that the Prime Minister had an obsession to get his own way. He got his own way with a few of these funny little organisations that have been abolished by the razor gang and others. But he also got his own way with things that were not examined, such as his own two private Boeing aircraft which cost $40m; the racing circuit which is to be built in Canberra-his pet hobby-at a cost of $2m; the Industrial Relations Bureau which costs $4m a year, I think, the abolition of which was recommended by the former Minister for Industrial Relations; and the defence academy known as Casey University which is to cost $80m-a private aberration of the Prime Minister-and something which was said by a joint committee of this Parliament, comprising Liberal, Labor and National Country Party representatives, to be an extravagance and unnecessary. The razor gang ignored the view of this Parliament on that issue and instead took the view of the Prime Minister. Other areas include Project Australia in respect of which there is a total commitment of $4m for a lot of rubbishy stuff which is put out basically in an attempt to tell the people of Australia that their problems are their own fault rather than the fault of the Fraser Government. The Government Information Unit and the octopus of the Department of Defence have received the gentle hand. One could mention the 101 tax rorts which the razor gang does not talk about. The sad fact is that many Ministers in this Government know nothing about all of this. They are told about it at the last moment.

This statement of the razor gang, so-called, does nothing to reduce the size of Government in Australia in any significant way. It is not a statement which affects the Commonwealth Budget to more than perhaps 0.5 per cent in recurrent Government expenditure. But the cost of implementing the proposals is significant. This statement is supported by flimsy rhetoric in which there is an incompetent display of an understanding by the Prime Minister of the functions of government in Australia and how these functions should be exercised. There is a good deal of rhetoric at the beginning of the statement about the Government's commitment to prevent centralisation of power in Australia. Under this Government in the last five years this country has moved more and more towards a corporate state. Small businesses are in a worse position than they have ever been. Honourable senators only have to look at their neighbourhoods to see the corner stores disappearing day after day in favour of multinational companies like BP, for example, which are running grocery stores.

TALK.START.PARA: —BHP, CSR-are they multinationals?

—The Minister can go through the list of multinationals until he is black and blue in the face as far as I am concerned. I am talking about the multinationals which operate grocery stores in Australia and are putting small businesses out of business. There has been a great centralisation of power. There is no better example of this than in the Prime Minister's own Department where staff has increased by 17 per cent since his tenure of office; Treasury has grown by 10 per cent; the staff of the Public Service Board has grown by 5 per cent; and the Commonwealth Police force has increased by 40 per cent. That is centralisation of power within government. Mr Peacock's charges about that are absolutely substantiated.

SPEECH.PARA: One could go on to deal with a number of other things which illustrate the Fraser Government's incapacity even to think out its own commitment on some of these matters. There is no consistent philosophy in the statement. The impact will be on the less fortunate members of the community who need resources and on the future of Australia 10 and 20 years beyond the next election. This report in no way applies itself to the proper functions of Government. We of the Opposition are not upset about these sorts of exercises except to say that they illustrate incompetent government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have fooled me.

—It is easy to fool the honourable senator. He is a sucker for that. We are not concerned that these inquiries should take place. What we are concerned about is that they should be handled competently and they should address themselves to the real functions of government. In the overall context of the Australian economy, this is what the Labor Party considers to be the proper function of the public sector: To promote the welfare of the most needy in this country; to provide information for the Australian community and the private sector; to intervene in the economy to stimulate competition and to promote efficiency and social justice, not to water down the provisions of the trade practices legislation; and to promote the genuine decentralisation of power in this country. The razor gang report addresses itself to none of those questions. As I said, its basic characteristics are incompetence and shallowness. For those reasons, it is to be condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating, as Senator Button has admitted, the general philosophies of two parties. The ideology of the Opposition, as its supporters themselves state, is one of socialism. The ideology of our Government is one of private enterprise. Socialism, of course, is the individual being subservient to the state. Private enterprise is the state being subservient to the individual. Senator Button has referred to the beady eyes of private enterprise being on anything that makes a dollar. But what is the function of government? Senator Button obviously has a totally different impression of the function of government from what we on this side of the chamber have. On that side of the chamber he believes that the function of government is to make a profit. He says: 'Let's make a profit; let's go into areas which could well be conducted by private enterprise; let's own Belconnen Mall, for instance'. During the Whitlam reign this Mall was built. The Government held on to it and made a profit out of it. Senator Button objects to its being sold. He objects to the people buying Belconnen Mall, running their own affairs and doing things which we on this side of the House believe private enterprise and the people can do far more efficiently and far more effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans was reported as wanting the best of both worlds. He wants the ideology of socialism retained in his party but he does not want us to know about it. He does not want it to be highlighted. He wants it to be low. He suggests that it be taken out of the written policy of the Opposition because it does not appear to be too popular at election time. There has been centralisation versus decentralisation. Right from the very beginning when this Government came to power in 1975 it brought in the concept of decentralisation of power. We believe the States, which are nearer to the people, should have the power, in accord with the provisions of the Constitution, to look after matters in a much better fashion than can the Government in Canberra. This is anathema to the Labor Party. It wants all the power centralised in Canberra. It is certainly bucking now at the razor gang's decentralisation program which has been brought forward in a bigger way than any other government has done in this country. We have underlined our policy and put it to the people, as we have done at the last three elections, and the people have supported us and said yes, this is what they want. They have rejected the socialism power policy of the Opposition. They rejected it in 1975 by the largest majority this country has ever seen and in the most positive way possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name one thing in this report which appeared in your last election platform.

—The whole philosophy of that report was in our election policy. Our Federalism concept-that is, returning to the States those things which the States can best do-was part of our election policy from 1975 on and has been part of our election promises. Our election promise was for smaller government. This is a positive step towards smaller government. But this matter was debated very thoroughly in this place yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal in the main with the health statement put forward by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar). I believe it is the best policy that we have had since our health system was interfered with by the Whitlam Government-that is, since Medibank. I agree with the Opposition when it ways that the previous systems which we introduced were half-baked. I agree entirely with any statements along those lines. This policy is not half-baked; it is responsible health policy. I do not believe for one instant that Senator Grimes, who is certainly knowledgeable in the health cost field, would not admit that health costs were going off the map. Every single Opposition senator knows that health costs have escalated beyond reason.

The Government has stated eight separate areas in relation to health, and I wish to refer to those areas. First, the Commonwealth Government's responsibility is to protect those in genuine need. I believe that is most important. Secondly, Australians should be more responsible for their own health through looking after their lifestyles in a more responsible fashion and that they should be made more aware of the costs of ill-health to taxpayers. Thirdly, the Government believes that those who can afford to pay should be required to pay and should not rely on others to pay for them. Fourthly, the Government believes it should be willing to assist those who can afford to pay and who do pay, but should not assist those who can pay but are not willing to pay. Fifthly, health insurance should be available to everyone at a reasonable cost. Sixthly, the private hospital sector should be acknowledged as a vital part of our health scheme. I am sure the Opposition would disagree with that principle, as it has done on many occasions. Seventhly, all those involved in providing health care services should be made more aware of the costs that they generate. Eighthly, the States must accept their constitutional responsibility for their health services.

I shall refer one by one to those eight statements which the Minister made. Firstly, honourable senators should look at the Commonwealth Government's responsibility to protect those genuinely in need. The Government believes that this is the area for which it, and not the States, should be responsible. As a result, it has taken on the responsibility of those who are disadvantaged. I shall read what the term 'disadvantaged' covers, because there has not been much discussion on this matter and the detail of it has not been put forward. Firstly, for migrants and refugees, in their first six months settling in period, the Government believes there should be no test. The Government will look after their health costs. The currently unemployed and special beneficiaries, including their dependants, with incomes below the pensioner health benefits limits, will not be classed as pensioners but will qualify under the health benefit but not the other fringe benefits.

In relation to a married couple-this is a new departure; it is not just in respect of pensioners and beneficiaries-for those who have a joint income less than the cut-out point for unemployment benefit for a married couple this would equal about $160 a week, plus $20 for each child. Therefore, for a married couple with three children the cut-out point would be $220 a week. On top of that $160 a week for that married couple, $20 is allowed for each child. That is an income which the Government believes should enable them to take over responsibility for their health care. For a sole parent with one child the income limit would be the same as for a married couple, that is $160, and again there would be an additional $20 for each child. For single people without dependants, the income limit will be sixty per cent of the income of a married couple, that is, $96 a week.

Over one million people will be classified as disadvantaged. The Commonwealth medical benefits scheme limit will now be 85 per cent as opposed to the 75 per cent for the disadvantaged which was previously suggested. This figure of 85 per cent is equal to the pensioner health card arrangements. A patient in this classification will be able to take his doctor's bill to any fund for payment. All he will have to do is show his identifying card, and the costs will be paid.

The second area I referred to was that every Australian should be made more responsible for his own health and should be made fully aware of the costs. It was suggested to our back bench committee when it was looking at this scheme that public hospitals should, when presenting a bill to a patient, print on the patient's bill the actual cost of the patient's stay in hospital. For instance, if a person has been in a big public teaching hospital in Sydney or Melbourne for five days at $250 a day, which is a rough estimate of the per day bed charge in such a hospital, that fact should be noted-the amount $1,250 should appear on the bill. Then the patient will be fully aware that the cost was much more than he or she is actually paying. Charges for pathology or other treatment should be added. In that way the patient will become aware that ill health is a costly business. It is also suggested that from this overall total the subsidy should be subtracted and the patient shown that what he or she pays is just a drop in the ocean compared with the actual cost. That would be a very commendable process and I would appreciate it if the State governments took up the suggestion. I believe that people are not fully aware of the heavy costs that these big hospitals undertake on their behalf.

The third area of Government concern is that those who can afford to pay should be required to contribute. I doubt that many members of the Opposition would suggest that the more wealthy members of our community should be able to use our public hospitals and obtain health care completely free of charge while many pensioners, because of their particular priorities and feelings of responsibility towards their health care, do without other things in order to pay for insurance. Many pensioners do exactly that. I believe it is an anomaly that pensioners should contribute to health insurance while wealthy people are allowed to use public hospitals completely free of charge.

The fourth area flows from what I have just said. The Government believes that, of those who can afford to insure, it should assist only those who are willing to do so. Because of its firm belief that people should be responsible for their own health care the Government has decided that medical benefits shall go to only those who care to insure themselves. Anyone who decides to go it alone and not insure will have to meet the full bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a compulsory system.

—It does not produce compulsory insurance at all. It represents a choice that some people may well make. Many Australians are gamblers at heart and will gamble that they will not have any health costs. They can do that. If they do, they should be fully aware of what they are undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifthly, health insurance should be available to everyone at a reasonable cost. The Government is fully aware of the complications inherent in joining the various health funds-the numerous tables, levels, ancillary services and additional services. It has insisted that only two tables be involved. First, there would be a basic table which would cover public hospital care and basic medical costs. It would represent relatively cheap insurance. The other table would embrace additional costs such as private hospital care and ancillary services. I believe that the use of these two tables will simplify health insurance for the majority of the community and will avoid the tremendous concern as to which table one should insure under, a factor that has worried so many of us in the past.

In addition, the Government has decided that basic hospital costs should attract a tax rebate. Once again, according to the policy that those less able to pay should not be disadvantaged, the Government has decided that there is to be a rebate of 32c in the dollar across the board for expenditure on basic tables; that means everyone will get the same rebate; that those who take out additional health insurance will not receive an added rebate in that respect. Whatever table one insures under one will still receive the same rebate. Those who take on the responsibility of insuring themselves should receive recompense by way of tax rebates.

Sixthly, the private hospital sector should be acknowledged as a vital part of our health scheme. The Government is aware that, as a rule, the small private hospitals are far more cost effective than are the big teaching hospitals or the bigger public hospitals. The Government is very concerned that such hospitals should be able to operate in an effective and efficient manner. The $16 a day bed subsidy that the Government has given to these private hospitals for so many years has been increased in respect of surgical hospital beds, which are the more expensive, to $28 a day. That proposal has been welcomed by private hospitals, which see it as contributing to a vital part of their viability.

Seventhly, all involved in providing health care services should be made more aware of the costs that they generate. Since the introduction by the Opposition of the first Whitlam or Hayden Medibank scheme people have been brainwashed into believing that there is such a thing as free medicine. There is no such thing as free medicine, free hospitals or free health. Since then the taxpayers have become aware that there can be no free health, that we must pay for it. With the new technology, the cost of health has grown tremendously. Medical students, from the beginning, should be made aware of the costs that they will generate when they complete their training. Committees have examined this problem of providers of health care being kept aware of rising health costs and have made many recommendations and the medical schools have taken these up. And a tremendous amount of education in this regard has taken place. An example of this is that, a couple of years ago, when the Government introduced a new scheme in respect of pathology, under which a doctor does not merely tick off from a prepared list the pathology services that he requires but makes out his own list, the temptation to tick more services than were necessary was done away with. That has been very successful. It is one way in which many costs have been saved. There is still a long way to go in this matter because, even if insurance companies meet the costs, doctors tend to over-utilise some pathology and diagnostic services. That fact should be driven home even more.

Eightly, and finally, the States must accept their contributional responsibility for the health services. There are two ways in which we could go about promoting this. The Jamison report said clearly that there was gross inefficiency in the public hospitals sector. Perhaps I could quite briefly from that report. It states:
The Cost-Sharing Agreements . . .
That is, the 50-50 agreements that are in place at the moment-
have rewarded the expensive and punished the efficient and have perpetuated rather than solved some of the main problems in Australia's health system.

Today the community cannot be expected continually to support by way of taxation and their own personal expenditure any wasteful and inefficient public hospital systems in Australia. We know that when nobody is responsible for the payment of a thing inefficiency occurs; no one is particularly interested in saving money in that case. We know, even amongst ourselves, that if we pay only half the bill we tend to add a few extra dollars. The States have indulged in that practice over many years. It has been particularly obvious in my State, and the hospital system in Tasmania is in a diabolical state at the moment. I put that down to the fact that no one is interested in paying the whole of the cost.

Because the Commonwealth constitutionally was not responsible for the hospitals, its hands were tied; and under the 50-50 sharing arrangements the State decided the amount it wanted and the Commonwealth was obliged to pay 50 per cent of that amount. As I said there are two possible methods of funding hospitals. Firstly, the Government could give to the States an amount of money which could be absorbed totally into the general revenue grants and the States could take that money and use it in any way they liked. They could use it for roads or for any other of their priorities. The other method is to fund by way of tied grants. The Government would give a certain amount of money to the States and the States would have to use that amount on hospitals and could add to it if they so desired. The Government has decided that funds for public hospitals, community health programs and the school dental scheme should be included in general revenue grants, but because radical and extensive change should not be made overnight the Government has decided that at the moment it will hasten slowly and that in the short term the money will be earmarked. The general idea is that it will eventually go into general purpose grants.

The agreements with the Tasmanian and South Australian governments do not expire until 1985. The 50-50 agreements between the Commonwealth and the other States expire this year. Tasmania and South Australia will have to decide whether they are going to take up this new system or whether they will continue the 50-50 agreement until 1985. I only hope that Tasmania takes up the new agreement, because if it does not the present scheme will continue. In Tasmania at the moment wards are being closed, pregnant women are being denied access to hospitals purely because they are insured, those responsible enough to be insured are being denied access to hospitals, surgical times are being cut in half and surgical patients are being denied access to these hospitals. Many pitiful examples of urgent cases that have not been able to go into hospital at the required time have been brought to the notice of the media, and that sort of thing is completely unforgivable. The States must end up by taking up this option from the Government. They have been given permission, if they so desire, to charge in public hospitals and to charge outpatients, so that people who are on high incomes must pay when they go into private hospitals. People will insure themselves if the State decides to do that. I believe it is important for our Premiers to look very closely at what the Government is offering. I sincerely hope that he does so.

Finally, I come back to the philosophies of the two parties. The health statement and the Review of Commonwealth Functions are philosophical matters. The debate today is purely an ideological and philosophical matter. The difference between the two sides must be clearly pointed out to the people of Australia. If the people do not want the cuts that this Government has suggested, the efficiences that have been underlined, the amalgamation of overlapping committees, the sale of the Belconnen Mall, for example-if they want socialism-then they can object to our policies. But let them understand very clearly that the Australian Labor Party at times in its history has tried to nationalise all sorts of institutions in this country. It tried to nationalise the banks. It tried to nationalise the insurance industry. Let us not be mistaken: The Opposition is a dedicated socialist party whose aim is nationalisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell the truth for a change?
—History shows that the nationalisation of the banks was taken to the High Court.
—When was the insurance nonsense that you talked about?

—If the honourable senator does not call it an attempted nationalisation of the insurance industry, I think the industry does. The industry has claimed many times that an attempt was made to nationalise it. The people must be made fully aware that the difference between the two parties is that the Opposition stands for socialisation and nationalisation of our industries but that this Government stands for private enterprise so as not to centralise all the power in Canberra but to give power, the decision-making, back to the States. That is in complete opposition to what the Labor Party puts forward. I seek leave to continue my remarks.

—I have only two minutes left. I will not bother to seek leave. I will finish my speech.
