DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH (PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981REPATRIATION (PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 5 May.
National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill
Clause 4.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering Senator Mason's amendment to this clause.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Grimes-Mr Temporary Chairman, may I just take a point of procedure? As we now have notice of an amendment to be moved by the Government which in fact would precede the one moved by Senator Mason, would it be sensible or possible to consider the Government's proposed amendment first?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will call on the Minister to explain the situation. I think that the procedure we should follow is as it is laid down before me.

—I understand that the Standing Orders provide that we should dispose of the amendment before the Chair first. The amendment before the Chair is, in fact, Senator Mason's amendment. I agree with Senator Grimes that it would be logical to do as he suggests, but we do have an amendment before the Chair. I am not going to argue the matter. We should debate and dispose of that amendment. I indicate, as honourable senators may know, that the Government has some amendments to move subsequently.
—I call Senator Mason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I speak to this amendment, would that exclude my right of reply and close the debate--
—No. You may continue. We are dealing with the Bill in the Committee of the Whole.

—I was concerned about that but there is no problem. Since moving this amendment to proposed new section 98BE of the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Bill late last night, I have had the chance to make further inquiries about its implications, including inquiries of officials of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. As a result, I am now even more concerned about the legislation as it now stands. I think it is fair enough to say that I do not think the Government amendment to be moved later, a copy of which I have seen, improves the position very much. However, I shall address my remarks to my own amendment. To give some background, basically this Bill sets up a Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to set pharmacists' fees for dispensing prescriptions under the National Health Scheme. The Australian Democrats obviously agree with that. A necessary mechanism is being created which has not existed in that form before. It is high time it did exist.

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential for everybody in Australia who is using health care or who may need it-after all, that means all of us-that there should be a fair, smooth-running system of dispensing the medicines which are such an important element of treatment. This is the job of the pharmacies. They have traditionally done this for a long time and there is no question of their not continuing to do so. They are involved intimately in the medical process and its proper procedure. Australia's 5,000 pharmacies deal with millions of Australians every year, dispensing, I understand, 100 million prescriptions in that time. So it is not a small business that we are talking about. It is a very large business and one that affects every man, woman and child in this country.

Whether these pharmacies can remain viable businesses making a reasonable profit is very much the business of this Tribunal. It is established to see that there is a reasonable profit margin in the area and that there is not an unreasonable profit. But it is also established to see that a continuous situation is provided which will allow the pharmacies to carry out this work they do on behalf of the community. At this stage I think it is important to stress that they do not have any option but to accept what the Tribunal says. Unlike doctors, pharmacists cannot say: 'Fees have been set at this amount but we are going to charge more'. That kind of situation will not obtain. I think it is fairly important to be aware of that.

The whole of this Bill has implications, as I have said, for all Australians because it involves the health process working properly. It has implications for those people in our society who are unfortunate enough to be ill, particularly for those who are unfortunate enough to be chronically ill and who depend utterly on these drugs and their availability freely at the time they need them. I suggest that this also is an important aspect of the general economics of the situation. Pharmacists who are not making a profit and who have heavy overdrafts will get to the stage where they might not carry stocks of various drugs which they would otherwise carry. Their service to the community at large-an urgent and important one-might be diminished to that extent.

For some perverse reason, which has still not been explained to honourable senators or, I gather, to anybody else-certainly not to the Pharmacy Guild-the Government has introduced a catch-22 situation into the small print of this Bill that severely and unfairly disadvantages the pharmacists. Those words in the Bill-they are the ones the Australian Democrats want taken out and they are the subject of the amendment we are talking about-in effect prevent the Tribunal from backdating its decisions. The position is as simple as that. I understand that no other tribunals or commissions are affected by provisions such as proposed new section 98BE which places these kinds of restraints on determinations.

I am informed that the existing Joint Committee of Public Accounts which sets remunerations for pharmacists in this area does have authority to make its decision retrospective. Almost invariably, all the increases it has granted have been backdated. There are very good reasons for this. It is not really possible to decide what the costs of things will be until a subsequent date. Unfortunately, in the second reading debate last night the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, said that there will not be any retrospectivity. The Government does not foresee any possibility of retrospectivity in this case. Senator Tate raised the question that perhaps the Tribunal had the power to make its decision retrospective anyway. We now know that that is not the case.

Senator Baume mentioned that medical tribunals set their levels of benefits payable without their decisions being retrospective. Of course, this is true. But the situation of the people concerned in those cases, as I mentioned a few minutes ago-it is worth stressing-is quite different from the pharmacists' situation. For example, once the appropriate tribunal has set the level of medical benefits that will be paid, doctors can and do raise their fees to cover past costs. Optometrists act in a similar fashion. This proposed new section, worst of all, ignores the fact that cost statistics can really be collated only after the event. Generally there has to be some kind of time-lag to discover actual increases in costs.

I would like to give an example of what might happen. For instance, the Tribunal might make a determination on 1 July 1982. On 10 July there might be a large increase granted under the award for work value for pharmacists' staff. So there is a significant increase in costs for the pharmacists. At that point the pharmacists have to prepare a case for the Tribunal to open an inquiry if one is not scheduled. That takes time. Presumably the Tribunal considers this case. The Tribunal announces that it will conduct an inquiry, say, on 1 November-a not unreasonable space of time. Any resulting decision by the Tribunal cannot set a fee to recover the pharmacists' costs between 10 July and 1 November of that year. Those costs could be very great-large enough to make what were previously profitable businesses completely unprofitable.

I have spoken to chemists in my office and they have told me that their shops have become unprofitable in recent months as a result of the erosion of the value of the fees paid for these benefits. I think that is an extremely valid complaint on the part of the Pharmacy Guild. I think its case is in all ways eminently reasonable. Many pharmacists-as I have said, there are 5,000 such small businessmen in Australia-have been having a very rough time financially in recent years and especially in recent months. The Australian Democrats believe that they rightly object to this unfair provision in the Bill.

I make an appeal to Liberal Party senators in particular to support this amendment simply on the grounds that it is fair and right that they should do so. It is the job of everybody elected to this place to do what is fair and right. The duty of honourable senators to the people who elected them and their duty to the community at large should go beyond any duty they have to any party structure. It is time for it to be said again and again in this country that no pressure group of any kind, be it the Liberal Party of Australia, the Australian Democrats or the Australian Labor Party, has any right to dictate to its members how they should vote on a matter of justice.

We believe this is a matter which should transcend politics and on which the Government should allow its senators a free vote. It should not start wielding big sticks at them over a matter which is very straightfoward and with which a number of Liberal Party senators have said they agree. We should not have the Gilbertian tragic situation that because of Government pressure on them they are to do something which is against their interests, against the pharmacists' interests and, indeed, against the interests of the community at large. I appeal to Liberal Party senators to support this amendment simply on the grounds that it is fair and right to do so. Liberals claim also to represent small business and that should be an additional reason for them to support the amendment.

Basically, it is fair and reasonable to remove those words and unfair and unreasonable to leave them in. All honourable senators know that full well. Why should the pharmacists have to carry a burden which they assess might be as much as $10m in a year? There is a further implication. Pharmacies are businesses. They have to make a profit of some sort or go to the wall. The higher their real costs are, the higher also must be the prices they charge the general public. That is the other implication of this rather stupid error in this legislation. I am convinced that that is what it is. It is no more than an error which has been perpetrated for some reason I cannot understand. This burden is being imposed unnecessarily on pharmacies. It will be passed on to every family in the nation. So the Government need not stand up and say that it is saving anybody any money by bringing forward this legislation because that is not the case. The burden will still be there, no matter how it is shifted around, and it will still be passed on to the public.

I repeat: The Government has given no reason for this legislation. I appeal to the Minister at this Committee stage of the Bill please to give the pharmacy industry, the public, the Australian Democrats and the Senate a reason for this absurd refusal to allow this amendment. I understand that the Labor Party will vote for the amendment. I hope so. The Australian Democrats, of course, certainly will, and we ask Senator Harradine, in all courtesy and respect, also to support it as he supported my second reading amendment to the same effect last night.

I now issue a direct challenge to Liberal senators. There are perhaps a few of them who are indeed genuinely liberals, genuine supporters of free enterprise, of private business and of small business. In that case, they will vote for this amendment and they will be respected and thanked for it. Or will they cringe away before the big stick of their master in the other place and meekly vote as the master has directed them to vote-against the amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! Why don't you talk a bit of sense?

—Well, Senator, I am just putting an alternative to you. You can think it through for yourself. In that case, I point out that if they do take that easy option, their dishonesty and deficiencies will become known not only to pharmacists but also to all of Australia's small businessmen and women. If they vote that way then the writing is on the wall for them. This grossly unfair treatment of the pharmacists is already being prepared for others. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this amendment, as I did last night, and in so doing I wish to comment on how we have arrived at this situation. We have a Bill which both sides of the chamber recognise is an urgent piece of legislation. Both sides of the chamber have co-operated in putting it through as quickly as possible. It went through the House of Representatives, with the agreement of the Opposition, in one day. It was intended yesterday that the Bill would go through this place in one day but, as Senator Mason has said, what seems to us to be a deficiency in the legislation-proposed new section 98BE-was drawn to our attention by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. This is a provision which, in an otherwise very worthy piece of legislation, a piece of legislation to set up an independent tribunal to overcome the difficulties which have been experienced in the past in determining pharmacists' remuneration, has put a limitation on the powers of that tribunal in that the tribunal cannot give recognition to retrospective costs and cannot bring down a retrospective determination.

SPEECH.PARA: I think people on both sides of this chamber last night, when we debated this legislation for some 2 1/2 hours because of the Government's intransigence on this matter, asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) for an explanation as to why this particular restriction was put into proposed new section 98BE. I suggest, as did Senator Mason, that we just have not been given a satisfactory explanation for that. We have been told two things. We have been told that it was a deliberate Government decision, but we have not been told why. We have been told that another tribunal, the medical tribunal which considers medical fees, has a similar provision in its legislation. I assume that is so; I have not had time to look it up. But that is irrelevant because doctors and optometrists, unlike pharmacists, can alter their fees at will and do so, and frequently ignore the provisions of the tribunal, something which the pharmacists simply cannot do. It has been suggested that the terms of reference of the legislation are so wide that in fact the tribunal can take into account retrospective increases in costs. We know that, of necessity, the determination of costs lags behind the actual infliction of those costs. So, I assume from Senator Peter Baume's explanation last night that we have the situation whereby the tribunal builds into its decisions actual figures on past costs and, I would assume to be just, estimates of future costs.

I think it was Senator Watson who said that this is a terribly messy way in which to go about things. Why not do it simply? Why not do it in a more just manner by allowing the tribunal to assess past costs and to bring down a decision which will pay back the pharmacists for those cost increases in the previous 12 months or six months. Another messy alternative would be for the tribunal to meet every two months, every three months or every four months, if necessary, in times of high inflation, or of unusual increasing costs. Why do it this way? Why, in this legislation of all legislation, in the words of the Minister, deliberately put in this restriction in proposed new section 98BE? Conversely, indeed, why not accept this amendment? Why not take out this provision?

The Government has distributed to us a further amendment. It is an amendment which clears up another question which was raised last night by honourable senators in this place and which was denied by the Minister as being a problem but which now obviously, it has been decided, is a problem. This amendment will clarify another section but it does nothing for the effect of porposed new section 98BE and it does not affect the amendment which has been moved. It seems to us and, I am sure, to many other people that what Senator Mason described as a Gilbertian situation has arisen, because of the stubborn- ness of the Government and the stubbornness of the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar), because of the Minister's refusal to admit that this restriction is unnecessary and that this restrictive proposed new section is in fact not only unnecessary but unjust. We all admit that this legislation has been unnecessarily delayed but we all admit that it is necessary for the justice of the pharmacists that it go through today or in the next couple of days. So why not accept this simple amendment which will do no more than make the work of the tribunal easy, much simpler than it is at present, and which will make things clear to the pharmacists and to everybody else in the community that in this piece of legislation justice is not only being done but is being seen to be done.

For that reason we will persist in our support of the amendment, an amendment which, as I said last night, was originally going to be moved from the Government side but which at the last minute was not moved from that side. It was taken up on this side of the chamber after I had led for the Opposition in the second reading debate. The whole procedure demonstrates the uncertainty of the Government, the problems it is having in the health area in general and its failure to come to grips with problems in this area. It is a small matter in the overall picture, but it is an important matter in this sort of legislation. We persist in our support for the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We debated this matter at some length last night and I do not wish to go into any detail this afternoon other than to try to identify the two ways in which to go about achieving a result which is intended to ensure that, so far as the chemists of Australia are concerned, and so far as the members of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and those other chemists who are not members of the Pharmacy Guild are concerned, they receive a reasonable opportunity for regular review of the payments which they receive from the Commonwealth in respect of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: One way which might have assisted and which last night some of us were considering was the proposal which has been put forward by Senator Mason. It is not the only way. There is another way in which what many people believe is a reasonable and a reasonably clear result can be achieved. That is a package which clarifies the matters which were debated last evening and which avoids the problem of retrospectivity. It can perhaps best be described in this way: Up to the first finding and determination by the new Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal there will, pursuant to the transitional provisions set out in clause 10, sub-clause (2) of the Bill, be the opportunity for full retrospectivity to 1 May last year. So the first determination does not then raise the problem which has been a matter of debate in this chamber. It is only from the second determination onwards that there is a question about this matter.

A number of honourable senators were concerned that there was potential ambiguity in the provisions of proposed new section 98BA, particularly when read in conjunction with proposed new section 98B. They were concerned about the effect of a provision which stated that inquiries should be conducted at intervals of not more than 12 months but which did not provide for determinations to be given at least every 12 months. If there is a provision which ensures that there is at least an annual determination as to whether the Commonwealth price of all or any pharmaceutical benefits should be varied, that will ensure that a period of no greater than 12 months will go by without an adjustment. There is also the need to clarify what may be taken into account by the Tribunal in determining the way in which it operates. I must say that until I had the opportunity to study the Bill in greater detail than I had studied it when we debated it last evening I was unhappy about the way in which the Tribunal was to operate under this legislation. I am only slightly less happy from a drafting point of view. I think the problem could have been got around in a better way, but I see the urgency, and I now see the practicality, of going ahead with the proposal which has been foreshadowed in the proposed amendment circulated by Senator Peter Baume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that better than the amendment which is before the Chair?
—May I finish and then come back to answer the honourable senator's question?
—It has nothing to do with the amendment.
—No, nothing at all.
—If I could finish explaining what I see as a package which clarifies the problems honourable senators might like to interject at that stage and I could answer their questions.
—But you will answer the question?

—I ask the honourable senator to interject again if I do not. I suggest that there was a problem which, if I can briefly reiterate it, involved clarity of drafting and the question of the period of adjustments and whether they could be made retrospective in their effect. I have pointed out that there is no problem in regard to the first adjustment which can be made retrospective and which it is agreed by all will be made retrospective to 1 May 1980. So far as the future is concerned, the proposed amendment which has been circulated will ensure that there is at least an annual determination at a minimum. There is also provision--
—So did the Bill.

—Senator Tate interjects: 'So did the Bill'. Perhaps that is not a universal view. The proposed amendment will ensure that it is a universal view and not a matter for debate. It was a matter for debate last evening. The third aspect is whether there can be any cost catch-up. Senator Mason in particular referred to the fact that there can be cost increases and that there may be periods in which the chemists suffer increases but do not get a determination which will cover those increases. It is my understanding from the statements which were made last night and which I understand can be reaffirmed that there is nothing in the proposed legislation which prevents the Tribunal from taking past costs into account and that a ministerial statement has made it clear that it is the Government's intention that the Tribunal will be able to take them into account in making a determination which will provide for a past costs catch-up.

SPEECH.PARA: There is further provision that the Tribunal may inquire whenever it is determined by the Chairman to be necessary. So, one imagines that it will be possible to have adjustments made from time to time throughout the year. Let us take a situation such as that which has developed in the wages scene. When a national wage case decision imposes an increase in respect of the costs to employers, the State wages boards meet immediately and pass on a similar benefit to State employees, and a whole lot of other cost fixing bodies, charges bodies, also meet to pass it on. So it automatically follows, I imagine, that there should not be any difficulty in the chairman of this Tribunal being able to ensure that, whenever that type of sudden cost increase arises, it can be passed on virtually immediately. The Bill does seem to retain the flexibility for the Tribunal to be able to meet whenever necessary. The chemists are assured that there will not be a lengthy period in which they have to carry costs. There is an assurance that past costs catch-up can be taken into account in a determination. The objectives sought by the Government in the first place, by those who spoke in the chamber last night and by the chemists of Australia, particularly members of the Pharmacy Guild, are met by what is proposed. It has the added virtue of being acceptable to the Government. It seems to me that the purposes sought can be achieved and that there is agreement by those involved. On that basis, I conclude what whilst the Pharmacy Guild, as I understand it, would have preferred its proposal it is quite prepared to accept the proposal which I have outlined and which the Government proposes to move in the form of an amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure that that is an accurate statement?

—It was reconfirmed a very short time ago. I can only say that I see this package as achieving the purpose which was debated last night. I see it as providing a degree of certainty and flexibility and an opportunity to ensure that the Tribunal can take into account past cost increases, but can meet whenever it is necessary. Certainly, I see it as meaning that the chemists will not be in a situation where there is a degree of uncertainty. Having said that, I inquire whether Senator Chipp wishes to interject further?
—You have not answered my question as to why you believe that the Government's solution is better than passing the amendment which is before the Committee.

—I thought I had done so. I put it this way: Taken as a whole together with the items to which I have drawn attention the legislation seems to me to achieve the purposes it is designed to achieve. I do not propose to play any part in keeping the Committee debating the semantics of whether one way or another way might have been better any more than I wish to go back and have the whole Bill redrafted because we could have started from a different proposition in relation to the establishment of the Tribunal in the first place. There are a number of aspects. I simply say that this legislation appears to me to achieve the desired purpose in a way which is acceptable. Therefore, I propose to support the amendment which has been foreshadowed rather than the one which is immediately before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed at the speech we have just heard from Senator Rae.
—I am not surprised.

—I am surprised because last night I believe several Liberal senators showed acceptance of the view that was put on this side of the chamber about the unfairness of this legislation to pharmacists and were prepared to look favourably at the logic that at that stage had not been answered by honourable senators on the Government side. As I listened to Senator Rae speaking, I thought not only of the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill, which we are now debating, but also of a far deeper question-the significance of the Senate. Does it have any significance nowadays? Do those people who spout the rhetoric that this chamber is a House of review that provides a necessary check and balance on the House of Representatives, that it is here to improve legislation, really mean what they say? Today senator after senator on the Government side of the chamber has stood up and said: 'This amendment should be carried but the Government will not accept it. Therefore we will not vote for it.'

SPEECH.PARA: For many years the Australian Labor Party had the abolition of the Senate as part of its platform. That is no longer part of its platform. I understand that it disappeared two, three or more years ago. Why do I mention that? I mention that because every time the abolition of the Senate was mentioned at a Liberal Party conference there were cries from outraged Liberals that this would be a dreadful thing for our country, that if the Senate were abolished the little person would lose its protection against the extravagances and excesses of an autocratic Prime Minister or an all-powerful political party in the House of Representatives which had the numbers to push through legislation by sheer party discipline. The Liberals said that the Senate provided protection for the little person. This Bill happens to be about the little person in the sense that pharmacists are small business people. They are a classic description of a small business person whose cause, I would have thought, the Liberal Party espouses and champions. It is rather strange that we now have the Liberal Party, jacked up by the discipline of the party room, voting against an amendment for the only reason that the Government will not accept the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.
—That is not so.

—I would advise certain of my friends opposite not to interject and contradict that statement, because they know it to be absolutely true. We are not talking about some rich, powerful lobby group, such as the doctors, who can and do unscrupulously raise fees, rip-off people and charge whatever fees they want. We are talking about a group of professional people whom I admire for undertaking such lengthy studies, at great sacrifice, to achieve professionalism in their field. They have to surmount numerous hurdles to become qualified in their profession. They have to have guts and courage to set themselves up in business, at massive capital outlay, only to find that a great percentage of their income is determined by politicians-by honourable senators and by members of the House of Representatives-who vote on Bills such as the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill that we are debating at the moment. A large part of their income is in our hands. They operate small businesses-the name that almost every politician, no matter what party he belongs to, grabs at every opportunity on the hustings and at every election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Senate, by the sheer weight of party numbers, going to do to these 5,000 small business people throughout Australia who fill 100 million prescriptions per year? This legislation seeks to establish a tribunal to fix the price for prescribing medicines. I commend the Government for its wisdom in introducing this legislation. Every speaker on this side of the chamber has similarly commended the Government for that. It is a good move. The Government ought to be congratulated, and I congratulate it. But what are we doing? Because of some drafting error in the legislation-there is a drafting error; that is the only conceivable reason for this provision being there-we have the Government instructing the proposed Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration that whenever it sits and receives evidence after its first determination it must not back date any price increase that it determines. In other words, the Tribunal may find that there have been cost increases because of circumstances outside the control of a pharmacist-namely, a massive increase in the salary or wage of his assistant or some other increase in costs, such as increased rent costs, workers' compensation costs, or whatever, but all the Tribunal can say is: 'Although you have been losing money for the last five years, the Government has said that because of an amendment to section 98BE of the legislation we are not allowed to back date any price increases'.

All that the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party are trying to do is to give the Tribunal such flexibility that if it believes that an increase should be back dated a month, five weeks, or whatever, it should be able to do that. That is all that this debate is about. We debated this matter for two hours last night, we have debated it for an hour today and we will probably bebate it for another hour, and that is all that the debate is about. Not one honourable senator opposite, including the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), has given us one good reason why this amendment should not be accepted by the Government. Senator Rae said-I quote him almost verbatim-that there is nothing in the legislation to prevent the Tribunal from taking past costs into account. I agree with that, but he is making sure that there is nothing in the legislation to give the Tribunal power to back date increases. In other words, Senator Rae concedes the merit of the point that is being put on this side of the chamber but will not agree to a simple amendment about a simple omission of words which will ensure the pharmacists' position.

An amendment to proposed section 98BA has been circulated by the Minister. In answer to my interjection, Senator Rae said that this amendment will fix it, that it will be satisfactory to the pharmacists. I tell him now that it is not satisfactory to the pharmacists. The amendment which will be moved by the Minister states:

(4) The Tribunal shall ensure that its findings resulting from its second or any subsequent inquiry, and the reasons for them, are issued not later than 12 months after the date on which the Tribunal issued its findings resulting from its first inquiry or from the last inquiry held by it, as the case may be.

I ask Senator Rae, Senator Jessop or whoever follows me to correct me if I am wrong in what I am about to say about my assessment of what that amendment means. My understanding of that amendment is that the Tribunal cannot go farther back than 12 months from the date of the last determination before it issues a new determination. My understanding is that it could go back 11 months and 29 days and then make a determination and fulfil the requirements of the legislation. During that 11 months and 29 days every pharmacist in the country could be losing his or her shirt because of price increases that the Tribunal cannot back date. If I am incorrect in my assumption and my interpretation of that amendment, I plead with Senator Watson or whoever follows me to tell me that that is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of interjection, may I help you? The Tribunal can convene itself at any time if someone makes a case that some extraordinary cost changes have occurred. The Chairman has the capacity to call it together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I consider it a great privilege and responsibility to have been elected to the Senate of Australia. I wish to place on record my sincere thanks and appreciation to the people of Queensland for their confidence, expressed in me at the ballot box; to the National Party for selecting me as one of its candidates; to all who worked for me; and to the members of my family for their encouragement and support. I would also like to express my appreciation to you, Mr President, and to honourable senators for the kindness and courtesy shown to me as a new member of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: In this my maiden speech there are a number of matters that I would like to put on record or correct. They concern my election as a senator and events in the Queensland Parliament which resulted in my coming to the Senate early. Firstly, it must be stressed that I stood for selection in the normal way. Like the other candidates, I had to face the National Party's governing body and put before it my arguments for selection as a Senate candidate. I must say here that but for a decision by the Liberal Party State Executive in Queensland to have a separate Senate ticket, the question of my being here might never have arisen at all. The National Party, by secret ballot, chose Senator Maunsell, Senator Sheil and me as its candidates for last year's Senate election. By another secret ballot at a State conference later, the party decided that I should head its Senate ticket. At the subsequent election, I topped the poll on the Government side and the National Party outpolled the Liberal Party. The National Party received 26.8 per cent of the overall vote, compared with 23 per cent for the Liberal Party. It is a matter for the public record also that, but for a leakage of 20.5 per cent of Liberal preferences, Senator Sheil would have been returned to the Senate. It should perhaps be stressed that the National Party certainly is not responsible for the Government losing control of the Senate after July.

There has been widespread comment, not all of it well informed or objective, on the background of my early entry into the Senate following the resignation of Senator Sheil to contest the 21 February by-election for the division of McPherson. The Queensland Government, as it is required to do constitutionally, had the task of choosing someone to fill the casual vacancy caused by Senator Sheil's resignation. It decided that I should enter the Senate at this time. The media soon carried reports about a superannuation windfall which I was supposed to gain because of the Queensland Parliament's decision. What people sometimes fail to recognise is that six years is a long time, especially when you are not really too young. I guess I have always adopted the attitude that God gives us one day at a time, and who knows what may happen. One has only to think of the death of Senator Knight. I am not alone in this position as far as the superannuation aspect is concerned, even in the Senate now, let alone after 1 July. Honourable senators will all know that I was not a member of this House when the relevant legislation on superannuation entitlements was conceived, considered and passed. Those provisions have been public knowledge since April 1980 when the legislation was passed by the House of Representatives and the Senate. However, the provisions were not discovered by the media until after the Queensland Parliament's decision, on 12 March, that I would fill the casual Senate vacancy.

I would also like to point out that some of my most vocal critics in this matter, including at least one Opposition member of the Senate from Queensland, have been strangely quite since Easter, when the new media discoveries in relation to superannuation entitlements were reported. I can assure the Senate and the people of Queensland whom I represent here that when I stood for selection I had not even inquired what a senator's salary was, let alone what were the superannuation entitlements. That was not the purpose of my standing. I would like to think that every honourable senator is interested in what he or she can do for our country rather than in what it can do for him or her. That is my attitude. I am in the unusual position of having been elected by the people of Queensland to take my place in this House from July next, and to have been selected unanimously by the Parliament of Queensland, comprising National, Liberal and Labor Party members, to replace former Senator Glen Sheil. No one can say in honesty that either process was not properly conducted.

At this stage I want to pay tribute to the work done for the people of Queensland by former Senator Glen Sheil. During his service to the Senate he was a hard-working senator who travelled Queensland widely and often and was interested in all the people and their problems. One problem that he was very concerned about and worked on was the matter of individual pensioners being allowed to earn $50 a week without either their pensions or their fringe benefits being affected. Let me say that I will be continuing Dr Sheil's strong advocacy in this regard. I do hope that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), whom I am glad to see sitting in the Senate chamber tonight, will be able to make provision for such a change when the Budget is brought down later this year. I have a wonderful opportunity tonight to tell him about that matter.

The State that I have the privilege to represent is very decentralised and diversified. It stretches some 2,400 kilometres from Brisbane to the islands of the Torres Strait beyond Cape York. The wealth that Queensland's development and productivity represents today is the envy of many States and of many people overseas. From the far-flung north to the northern, central and western inland, right down the coastal regions, Queenslanders and Queensland's projects in regard to cattle, grain, sugar, minerals, tourism and many other industries are contributing enormously to the welfare of the nation. The State is experiencing an unprecedented resource development boom, one which will be vitally important in meeting Australia's and the world's energy needs in the years ahead. I was interested to read in the Australian a couple of days ago, in regard to the resources boom, that the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors had predicted that the biggest expansion in the construction industry would occur in Queensland, which has the lion's share of the nation's planned projects. Projects worth $16,000m will begin in Queensland before 1987.

Geographically we may be an island, but we cannot isolate ourselves from the rest of the world and from the world energy scene in terms of harnessing and applying, for the general good, the abundant resources which God has given us. Our coal is no good to anyone if it is in the ground. It becomes of value to society only when it is mined or otherwise extracted and used, as do our uranium, our oil and gas, our oil shales and so on. I do not think anyone would seriously suggest that there should be a development at all costs approach, either in resource developments or anything else. But governments owe it to society to ensure that developments which are in the public interest are not stopped, slowed down, prevented or costed out of the range of people they could benefit by unrealistic government attitudes, regulations, restrictions or controls on foreign involvement or investment and actual development, export and conservation practices.

In the primary industry field it is generally acknowledged that Australia could immeasurably improve its productivity and its economic performance and safeguard itself against the vagaries of the seasons by stepping up considerably its commitment to water resource development. This should be part of the Government's overall view and policy on energy and resource development. I think we need only look at the tremendous drought in part of the south-west of Queensland-I heard today about the tremendous drought in parts of western New South Wales-to realise just how important this matter of water conservation really is. The Burdekin Dam scheme in north Queensland, some 40 years on the drawing board, is at last becoming a reality and will have tremendous long term benefits for the primary industries and the people relying on those industries in that part of our State. The scheme, when fully functional, will in fact transform the primary industry picture over a large area of the north. The people of Israel and California have shown the world that one can grow almost anything almost anywhere provided one has the water and applies it properly. In Queensland we certainly have the water-at least in a good season-which could be harnessed and applied more effectively if we as a federal government were committed more tangibly to confronting and beating the problems of drought, flood and rural productivity. In the research area there is concern about natural water storage levels in parts of central and south-western Queensland, but more extensive research is required to provide all the answers that are needed.

Tourism in Queensland, as in many other parts of Australia, is on the crest of a wave. In fact our tourist Minister said over the weekend that tourism in Queensland could produce more than 50,000 jobs by 1985. He said that eventually it would become the number one industry in Queensland. I think he has a long way to go but, never mind, it sounds as though the Queensland tourist industry really is booming. The Tourist and Travel Corporation, headed by Mr Frank Moore, is promoting Queensland tourism around the world as never before. The Government's decision to allow a direct approach to Townsville by Qantas Airways Ltd is very welcome but there is a real demand for more airlines to be allowed to bring tourists from around the world directly into our State. From Kagoshima, Japan, direct to Townsville is only seven hours flying. This route could bring hundreds of thousands of people to Queensland to spend their money and to see the wonders of our tourist areas.

Sixteen hundred kilometres to the west is Birdsville-and one is still in Queensland. Birdsville's greatest population influx comes each year with its race day for the Flying Doctor Service. What would the far flung parts of all Australia do without that wonderful service, initiated in Queensland as the brainchild of the late Dr John Flynn aided by Alfred Traeger and the pedal wireless system? In the far south-west of Queensland there are many cattle and sheep properties whose main enemy is drought. The Federal Government should recognise their plight by giving them taxation exemptions for a number of years when they commence to produce again after a good season. I am afraid out there they have not too much hope of water conservation. The present income averaging provisions simply do not meet the needs of the inland.

Despite those problems everything adds up to a great State that we know as Queensland, a State that provides more than one quarter of the nation's export earning wealth from only 15 per cent of the population. I point out that that money goes to the benefit of the whole of Australia. Queenslanders see little of it. On top of that, Queenslanders have to pay tariffs on a wide range of goods to prop up industries based in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. It is very disappointing to know that Queensland will be $130m poorer in real revenues from the Commonwealth after the Premiers Conference held here this week. The injustice is that Queenslanders are still paying taxes for those services, which taxes the Federal Government is going to keep while demanding that the States impose their own taxes. I would like to know just by how much the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is going to reduce the tax burden on the Australian people.

Last year's figures showed that more than 50,000 new settlers came to Queensland to live and work and many of those came from southern States and from New Zealand. They came because of greater opportunities and no doubt also because of good coalition government. Queensland has more towns with more than 30,000 people than any other State. It is growing so rapidly. In fact Queenland's population is increasing at a rate of 2.29 per cent a year compared with an average of 1.34 per cent for Australia as a whole. It is a State which I love and whose people I know so well. Over the past 10 or 11 years I have travelled from north to south and east to west meeting the people and talking with them. As a senator it is my intention to continue doing that in the years that I am privileged to be one of Queensland's representatives in this place.

There is one matter I would like to speak about which I feel should be of concern to all Australians; that is, the need for adequate defence and adequate expenditure on defence. We need to be able to defend Australia. We have a very long coastline and a very big country. When we consider all the Russian ships in the Indian Ocean and Russia's aggressive attitude around the world-I think of Poland and Afghanistan, to name just two places at present-we are only deluding ourselves if we declare the Indian Ocean an area of peace. The only thing that Russia respects is strength. As far as American bases in Australia are concerned, I support our Government's policy of working with America in the defence systems that that country has in Australia. I feel that the Australian Labor Party stands condemned for its attitude in this regard, particularly for the recent performances of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden. I remind Mr Hayden that the people of Australia fortunately have not elected him and his party to govern and to make those decisions of which he is now so critical or vocal. That power rests with Mr Fraser and this Government, of which I am happy to be a part.

In the case of social welfare, now a budgetary monster, let us not forget that it was a previous Labor government which created the monster and let it loose and we, as a government, now still face the problem of achieving the services we need and can afford rather than those that are demanded. I have long advocated that people ought to do the equivalent of the so-called dole payment in work. This work could be done either for local authorities or for private enterprise where the full basic wage would be provided. If the Government would agree to do it on this basis for, say, six months, many of the people now on the dole could become absorbed into the work force. I believe the great majority of people would like to work and play a useful role in the community. Unfortunately the International Labour Organisation says that we cannot direct people where they have to work.

Road funding is a vexed question which I know worries many motorists and authorities in all States. Last year Queensland motorists paid the Commonwealth Government $667m in fuel taxes, yet Canberra returned only $117.5m in road funding to Queensland. Senator Carrick, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, told me in a reply to a question that all taxes go into a common pool. I do not feel that that is justice when one considers that Queensland-just listen to this-has an area larger than Great Britain, France, East and West Germany and Italy combined. I would like to remind my Victorian senator friends that Victoria will fit into Queensland seven times. The Queensland road network covers 192,000 kilometres, including 42,000 kilometres of declared roads which are the direct responsibility of the Main Roads Department. No wonder the Queensland Government and the Minister in Queensland are continually registering complaints about the Federal Government's refusal to recognise this fact.

I wish to raise the issue of family life in Australia. Despite claims to the contrary, the family still remains the best way of caring for Australia's children and guiding them to adulthood. I was very interested to listen to Senator John Martyr make his maiden speech last week-it was a very good speech-and to include in it reference to the value of life, born and unborn. I feel that in some sections of society babies are becoming an endangered species. We talk about saving the whale and saving the seal. I have gone down the corridors of this building and seen signs about these matters on some of the members' office doors. We talk about saving the kangaroo and saving the elephant, but alas, not the babies to help our population growth. It seems to me that we, as a government, are making it more difficult, not easier, for families.

All parties acknowledge that the single income family is being hit hardest by rising living costs and higher taxation. We need positive measures to help families and we need them now. The system of family allowances introduced by this Government goes part of the way. However, I point out that these allowances have not been updated since 1976 and their value has been eroded. However, I believe that the simplest and most efficient way to help single income families is through a system of income splitting for taxation purposes, with the husband and wife dividing their income and paying tax accordingly. It is becoming increasingly difficult for single--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about flat tax?

—I will come to flat rate tax afterwards. It is becoming increasingly difficult for single income families to meet education, health, housing, transport, clothing and other costs of the family to keep the family together. The cost of maintaining an average wife-notice I say 'average wife'-including housing, clothing, food, electricity and medical expenses, et cetera, would have to be in excess of $2,500 a year. Children vary in age and numbers within the family and the cost for them could range between $1,000 and $2,000 a year. Costs for a working husband would average $3,000 a year. What is left over is disposable income or, in crude terms, excess income and therefore it should be taxed accordingly, probably on a rate in excess of that which now applies.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment, the money used to care for the necessities of life is taxed and, regrettably, even more severely in the case of families. It seems a poor society that will allow deductions for a businessman's car but will not allow them for the country's young. If correct tax deductions are applied, the family will no longer be at such a great disadvantage and the family unit will actually be encouraged. However, at the moment, under the existing tax scales, the single person has a far greater disposable income than that of the family unit. However, income splitting offers the prospect of providing some meaningful relief for single income families. It is an option that I feel the Government should look at.

During the Senate election I campaigned on the platform of flat rate tax. I intend to continue that campaign. I will tell honourable senators a bit more about that. It is a fact that the present system of progressive income tax penalises Australia's productive people. It is a disincentive to work, to save and to enterprise and eventually it will destroy the nation. Alternatively, it will turn it into a socialist nation, destroying private enterprise. Every Federal government since that of Sir Robert Menzies has promised tax reform and done little about real reform. The vast majority of Australians are in what might be termed the middle class and they are paying for the majority of the services. They are getting disillusioned with the fact that the Government will not recognise that they are being overtaxed. They want less tax, less regulation and less government.

Successive Federal treasuries, of course, have a nice little thing going in their favour because inflation silently keeps pushing more and more people into higher and higher tax brackets. This has meant more and more taxation revenue. To the sceptics who have criticised me and the National Party over flat rate tax, I say that there is nothing mysterious or even radical about flat rate taxation. In Australia every tax levied by the Federal Government is a flat tax, except personal income tax. Yet the idea of flat rate personal income tax has brought cries of alarm from a curious coalition of opponents. The socialists, of course, are horrified that government income will be reduced. I can understand their reaction because they make no secret of their expansionist policies and plans. But on this side of the political fence, the opposition is more puzzling. Big government and big taxes do not go with free enterprise. We constantly hear about encouraging investment in Australia, giving the small shareholder a go, boosting consumer spending and spurring on the building industry. Yet we, as a government, seem to make sure that the average Australian does not have too much left to do all these desirable things.

If we had flat rate personal income taxation, what would Australians do with their tax savings-bury them in their back yards? Of course not. They would put them into the bank. They would buy those things they need or they would invest the savings in the resources boom they have heard so much about. One can argue about the size of the flat tax rate, but there is no doubt in my mind that it is a far better scheme than the present tax system, with the proviso that pensioners and other people living on small fixed incomes, such as superannuation, are protected. Flat rate personal income tax would not necessarily reduce the income of the Federal Government in the long term. In fact, the income would build up because of greater growth in productivity, employment and the economy. It would give people greater personal freedom in the spending of their incomes. My plea is that we reduce the number of tax scales from seven to three. Let us hasten up the process and get down to a single, flat rate tax scale quickly to restore incentive to the wage-earning and taxation processes.

Everyone who supports our free enterprise society would agree that we need meaningful tax reform now and a flat rate tax is the concept which an increasing number of leading economists in Australia are coming to accept and support. Even Milton Friedman agreed that it was a worthwhile suggestion. I remember when it was said that death duties could not be eliminated until Queensland did it and showed how it could be done. The net result has been an increase in income for the Government in my State and increased employment and prosperity for Queensland. There are also arguments against tax cuts, but I remind the Senate that President Reagan has firm plans to do just this. With the greatest deficit of all time and high inflation and unemployment rates, President Reagan still believes and knows that the solution lies in lower taxes to give greater incentive to the people. He has to convince Congress of that just as our party has to convince the Government.

If anybody cares to read the history of the great Ford motor organisation during the great Depression years, he will find that the original Mr Ford reduced the price of his cars to the point where he received only 13/6d profit per car. As a consequence, he gained enormously. He not only kept his company viable but built it up as well. Other car manufacturers of that time did the opposite. They increased the prices of their cars. As a result they sold fewer cars, reduced profits and added to unemployment. I believe that we need not just a reshaping of the tax system but a new tax system. This should be followed by a constitutional referendum giving a fixed percentage of revenue to each level of government as a right, not as a matter of bartering to agree on a percentage. All three levels of government could plan with confidence and know that they must live within their percentage allocations.

In conclusion, I say that I am glad to be a member of this Senate. I regard myself as an Australian from Queensland. It is my intention to represent my State, as I believe it is the intention of all honourable senators to represent their States, but also to play my part for our nation. The motto on our national Coat of Arms is 'Advance Australia'. That, too, is my aim.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Durack) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is to enable the Government to implement important elements of a new policy for industrial research and development grants. It will also allow another five-year program for industrial research and development incentives. The Bill is part of the Government's response to the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia announced in the House on 18 September 1980. Our general objective is to make the Australian manufacturing sector more export oriented and more competitive against imports. A major factor in achieving this objective will be the success of the Government's general economic policy. As well, the Government's general industry policy approach has two broad strands: Firstly, to give encouragement to activities which are efficient, internationally competitive and export oriented via such measures as export, innovation and investment incentives, and secondly, to achieve, in the long-term, an industry structure requiring minimum levels of government support.

The existing Act, which expires on 30 June this year, was introduced in 1976 and provides for funding commencement and project grants as well as projects of industrial research considered to be in the public interest. This Government believes it is vital to encourage industrial research and development. Funding has risen from $14m in 1977-78 to $54m in 1980-81-nearly a four-fold rise within three years, despite the need for continuing expenditure restraints. Under the new program, commencement and project grants and public interest projects are to continue for a further five years. However, they are to be brought more into line with the other aims of the industry development policy. Project grants will remain the main focus of the new program.

Recently the Government has been urged to stimulate industrial research and development by a number of expert committees including, the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia-CITCA-and the Australian Science and Technology Council-ASTEC. Their advice was taken into consideration in developing the program which I am about to announce. Basically the Government has decided to become more selective in providing assistance. The rationale for government assistance rests on the proposition that there are disparities between the private and national returns from research and development expenditure. The market does not provide enough incentives for firms to undertake research and development. The result is a national under-investment in industrial research and development and a tendency for firms to concentrate on relatively short-term industrial research and development. The fundamental purpose of the program is to correct this market failure.

Against this background, the Government has decided that, in future, an industrial research and development project will be supported only where it involves a substantial degree of risk or where a firm is unable to gain enough of the profits generated by the industrial research and development to justify the project. The Government has also decided that policy measures should be cost-effective, be designed to improve rather than impede the operations of the market and that objectives should be spelled out clearly.

The Bill proposes that regulations be promulgated to ensure that project grants applications are ranked according to their potential contribution to industry policy objectives. However, for practical timing and flexibility reasons, it is proposed initially that these guidelines be issued to the Board as directions under section 19 of the principal Act. Firms will be required to maintain a sizeable financial stake in subsidised industrial research and development to ensure their motivation for success is not diminished.

To compensate for inflation as well as to strengthen the incentive to firms to undertake the industrial research and development, the Government proposes to increase ceilings from $500,000 to $750,000 per year for project grants and from $25,000 to $40,000 per year for commencement grants. The grants will remain taxable. For ongoing commencement grants the rate for the following year will be announced on March 31 and will not exceed 50 per cent. The project grant rate shall not exceed 50 per cent without ministerial approval.

The Bill makes provision for the inclusion of industrial research and development related to and carried out at the site of a building and is retrospective to 1 July 1980. Eligibility does not extend to more general operations in the industry such as works. The Bill allows computer software research and development to be eligible for project grant assistance under the Act but only when it is relevant to the objectives of the Act. It must relate directly to new products of, and new or improved processes employed in manufacturing, mining or eligible on-site building or construction activities.

The Government's intention is to encourage the application of new or innovative software techniques to the development of such products or processes. However, where computer software research and development has been eligible under the commencement grant scheme, this eligibility will be retained after 1 July 1981. In accordance with CITCA recommendations and with Government decisions on that report, the Bill includes a section on the Board's powers and functions. In broad terms, these are: To authorise the payment of industrial research and development commencement grants to eligible companies; to enter into agreements for projects of industrial research and development carried out or proposed to be carried out by eligible companies; and to enter into contracts for projects of industrial research in a field of science and technology where the Minister considers this to be in the public interest. The Board will be restructured and chaired by someone outside the Public Service.

The Bill contains provisions to enable the Board to obtain specialised advice in technical and commercial areas. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) shall obtain advice, on the selection of public interest projects by a re-constituted Industrial Research and Development Incentives Advisory Committee. The Advisory Committee shall take into account guidelines. The project must, firstly, be of high priority in terms of Government policy objectives; secondly, have substantial social and economic benefit to the community; thirdly, normally involve the commercial development of public sector or non-profit research institutions; and fourthly, be of major importance and likely to command widespread public support. As well, the guidelines will specify that funding should be for industrial research and development and should not be in the place of other funding sources.

Ownership of the results of public interest projects will be vested in the Commonwealth Government with commercially viable prospects being exploited on normal business terms. In future the Board's annual report will include statements of the names of companies with which the Board has made arrangements, the progress of their projects, and, payments to those companies. Directions from the Minister to the Board also will be included in the report.

The Bill repeals the Industrial Research and Development Grants Act 1967. The Government will be monitoring the operation of the new scheme to evaluate its effectiveness against the principles which I have just outlined prior to the Act's expiry in 1986. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Designs Amendment Bill. I wish to make a few necessarily brief comments about it. We regret the fact that over a considerable period there has been delay in bringing this legislation forward in the Parliament. I think this matter goes back a number of years, and that is unfortunate. But now the legislation is here we welcome it. I might say that tonight the Government has been very quick in bringing the Bill before the Senate; the Government did not actually tell us that it was coming on. The Designs Law Review Committee, headed by Mr Justice Franki, was set up in 1970-more than ten years ago-and reported in 1973. Years later, legislation resulting from that Committee's deliberations now surfaces.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to bring the principal Act, which was first passed in 1906, into conformity with changes in the law elsewhere and in particular with changes in Great Britain that have resulted from case law in that country. The effect of proposed new section 18 of the Act is to ensure that designs which can be judged by the eye because of their features or shape will not now be excluded from being registered as designs merely because shape or configuration features serve a functional purpose. Anybody who is listening to this debate and who does not understand the foregoing is in almost the same category as I am.

I wish to say something about the attitudes of this country, which I regard as being unfortunate, to questions of industrial property generally and to design matters in particular. We have always had the problem in Australia of trying to determine what we should consider our country to be. Should we consider it as a developed country, an undeveloped country or a lesser developed country-an LDC as such countries are sometimes called? Australia conventionally fancies itself as a rather developed country. It has the high living and educational standards of countries which can claim to be well developed or highly developed. We are European and Western in culture and outlook. But the real question is whether, in terms of national government and standards in relation to the matters which are the subject of this Bill and the other two related Bills, Australia is in fact a developed country or whether we are perhaps kidding ourselves a little in that regard. Culturally, we came to assume the semblance of being a developed country by virtue of our history, but economically it was on the basis of the great pastoral and mining industries in Australia that we attained the degree of economic sophistication that we have today.

Australia was and is an important source of raw materials. Exports of those raw materials paved the way for the development of the infrastructure of service industries, and later manufacturing industries, which our political and cultural structure demands. This was all very fine while the population was smaller, while the influence of multinational corporations was much smaller than it is today and while the greater part of the rest of the world was much less developed than it is today. It was also fine while we were not competing with the growing and increasingly sophisticated economies of South East Asia. I refer particularly to such countries as Korea, the social experiments of which we might not like to follow-I would not particularly like to follow them-but aspects of the economic development of which contain some lessons for a country like Australia. While in days gone by we were not competing with these growing economies of South East Asia our position was much easier. It meant, for example, that a policy of import substitution and fragmented growth was workable for manufacturing industry in Australia.

Times have now changed. Countries such as Korea, to which I have pointed, are moving up the economic scales and are developing relatively sophisticated methods of handling the introduction of new technology-not, as I have said, on the social side, but in relation to technological transfer-so that it benefits others besides the multinational corporations which take it to such a country as Korea. I would argue that in relation to the matters which are the subject of the three Bills which were originally to be dealt with cognately we should look very much to the examples set by countries such as Korea, Sweden and, perhaps more particularly, Norway. I do not mean that we should necessarily accept the social and political order of those countries, but Australia, as a recipient of multinational corporation capital and technology, should look at what these countries are doing in relation to the transfer of technology. We must recognise that Australia has a lot in common with them and that it has a sort of hybrid character in that it is in some ways a highly developed country-certainly in terms of aspirations-and, in other ways, it is a much less developed country. It is in relation to these matters that I think this type of legislation, and its subject matter, is important. I think we have to recognise that Australia is not in the big league of economic performance in these areas.

I refer the Senate to two views which have been put forward. One was put forward in a paper by Dr Paul Grant of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation which was read at the Australian Mining and Petroleum Law Association conference in Sydney recently. It dealt with the international transfer of technology for the secondary processing of minerals in Australia. This is an important topic because mining development, in spite of protestations to the contrary in this Senate, will not provide all the jobs that Australia needs, and secondary processing and manufacturing based on it could go much further towards the production of jobs and, indeed, permament wealth arising from the extractive industries. Dr Grant argued in that paper that we pay too much for overseas technology and that we allow multinational corporations to import it in package deals, which are tightly controlled, so that it is available to them and not to others. This casts some doubt on our hitherto solid support for a patent system which operates basically to the advantage of industrially developed nations and not to the advantage of a lesser developed nation such as Australia. This matter is very important in relation to secondary processing.

I have referred also to the Korean experiment. It has been argued successfully in that country that an industrially undeveloped country should put research last in development, after engineering and adaptation of overseas technology. That requires the wringing of some concessions from the providers of multinational capital in Australia, which this Government has never been prepared to do. Changes in our patent law may be necessary to adapt to that sort of system. We should also adopt a more aggressive stance in bargaining with transnational companies in relation to the importation of technology into Australia. The whole realm of industrial property law and industrial property practices is relevant to these questions of technology import. They are important matters to be considered in the light of the general subject of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that in some ways it is unfortunate that this second reading debate does not address all three related Bills insofar as we could have had a wideranging debate on the whole question which Senator Button has opened up and to which I think he has certainly contributed in many ways tonight. —I spoke very briefly on this subject just before the suspension of the sitting because we wished to report progress. National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1981

You will be aware that this Bill was rushed through all stages in the House of Representatives last Thursday and is to be considered by the Senate this week. Hence the short notice of these representations.

The legislation is to establish an independent public Tribunal to determine the amount of money paid by the Government to chemists as reimbursement of their out-of-pocket expenses incurred in dispensing pharmaceutical benefits prescriptions.
In principle, The Pharmacy Guild of Australia welcomes the legislation. Chemists have had no effective increase in their fee since 1977 during which time the CPI has increased by nearly 40 per cent.
However, Australia's 5,000 chemists are opposed to the legislation in its present form.

In the past, the method mutually agreed by the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia for adjusting chemists' remuneration was to allow them to recover the average cost of dispensing pharmaceutical benefits prescriptions. The arrangement was to establish as far as possible the increases in the average actual cost of dispensing after the event and to adjust payments to chemists for the relevant period.
However, the current bill under Section 98BE specifically precludes the Tribunal from making such adjustments.
It will enshrine in legislation a system of reimbursement to chemists where the level will always fall short of their actual costs incurred by the amount of inflation since the last determination.

May I re-emphasise that what we are talking about is not the payment by the Government of a wage or salary but the recovery of costs incurred by chemists in maintaining a critical element in Australia's health care system, that is, the dispensing of 100 million prescriptions per year.
Accordingly, my Guild recommends that the Bill be amended as follows:
Delete from Section 98BE all words after and including ''not'' in the second line of the Section (See Attachment).
This would otherwise preclude the Tribunal from adjusting determinations to match chemists' actual increases in costs.
If the Bill is not thus amended, then the Parliament will have placed constraints on what is supposed to be an independent Tribunal.
It is the Tribunal, not the Government, which should determine the level of remuneration and from what date that remuneration should apply.
In its present form the legislation is asking chemists to provide, out of their own pockets, a continuing subsidy of the Government's Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme of over $10 million per annum.

I am sure that you will appreciate the unreasonableness of the legislation in its present form and of the vital need for it to be amended by the Senate, if this essential element of Australia's health care system is not to be placed in jeopardy.

Senator Jessop has expressed concern about this matter and intends to raise it in the party room. I ask you to give the matter your earnest consideration and I look forward to your support for the amendment.
Yours sincerely, D. M. GIBBONS Executive Director
