SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before addressing my remarks to the ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions, I must do my duty and acknowledge the maiden speech made tonight by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I think the speech will be read with great interest by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, and the head of the Department of the Treasury, Mr Stone. I must thank the good senator for helping us. Too much in the past we have put up with hurt and angered speeches from the Government benches about Opposition speakers who have made provocative remarks in their maiden speeches. I believe that she has set a very sensible precedent in ignoring a tradition. It was certainly the most provocative maiden speech I have heard for some time, perhaps since Senator Walsh's maiden speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The Review of Commonwealth Functions presented in this ministerial statement, I believe, should be considered in the context of the Government's stated philosophy which seems to be that this country would benefit from a massive withdrawal of the Commonwealth from the public sector by transferring functions to the private sector and, in fact, to the States. It also should be viewed in association with other actions of what must be the most conservative Government in this country for the last 60-odd years. It is therefore appropriate that in the debate on this matter I follow Senator Walters, as I often seem to do in this place. There seems to be a plot to keep Tasmanians together. The honourable senator, of course, gave us a lecture of her views on socialism. She apparently believes that socialism means subservience of the individual. Whatever her philosophy is-she did not give it a name-it means the subservience of the state. It is a pity that she sometimes does not listen to the words of her leader the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

One week ago I was in Amsterdam at a meeting of the Socialist International. The chairman of that meeting was Willy Brandt. The representatives from the West German Government included three Ministers. There was an apology from Helmut Schmidt, who is the Chancellor of West Germany. They are all good socialists. We have frequently heard the Prime Minister of this country in fact praising the socialist Government of West Germany. We have heard other members praise the socialist Government of Austria which, of course, has a much better economic performance than our Government. I well remember one magnificent photograph of Prime Minister Fraser, Helmut Schmidt, Michael Manley and James Callaghan-all members of Socialist International and all socialists-all enjoying themselves and all expressing their views, which were the same, on the world's problems at the time. Of course, Mr Fraser's support for another avowed socialist, Mr Mugabe, who is not a member of the Socialist International, is well known. Perhaps Senator Walters should get her facts right. Perhaps she should do some reading. Perhaps she should, in fact, find out just what democratic socialists are, and who they are and she should look at some of the countries in this world which have democratic socialist governments. Then she may not be as critical, as blind or as narrow as she demonstrated herself to be.

As I was saying, this review committee represents a transfer of the functions of the national government to either the State governments or the private sector. It even brings about the abolition of some functions completely. It does not, in fact, represent a great reduction in expenditure in this country in relative terms but it does fit in with the general abrogation of the Government's responsibilities to provide for national standards for some aspects of the quality of life for ordinary citizens, in particular, disadvantaged citizens. If we proceed on this path this national Parliament will be reduced to considering defence, foreign affairs, and perhaps some pensions. Senator Martyr may well agree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—He may well agree that that is all we should do in this place and that all this national Parliament should do, unlike all other national parliaments in the world, is sit here and waffle about foreign affairs, defence and perhaps a few pensions to salve our consciences. I think it is worth quoting from the first page of the review committee report. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Review's starting point is that Australia's greatest resource is the Australian people and that the role of government is to enable people to exercise their abilities, their skills, their imaginations and their enterprise. When this happens the result is economic growth, more jobs, higher incomes and a better life for all. If we ask why it is that the free and democratic nations of the West provide the best way of life for ordinary people, the unmistakable answer is that it is because people who live in these societies are free to build for themselves the kind of life that suits them best.

The assumption in this sort of nonsense and the assumption by the Government is that government activity and public services, in fact, are necessarily bad, that they are against economic development and that they are against sound economic management. We hear frequently from Government spokesmen that Australia is particularly badly affected by an excess of public expenditure and by an excess of government involvement in the lives of the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —And by huge deficits, too.

—The truth is, of course, that on the international scale we do not have a large public sector. We are in the bottom league of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and many of the great Western democracies to which this review committee refers. They perform much better than we do when the usual economic parameters of inflation, unemployment and economic growth are measured. They do this, despite lacking the resources that we have. All have much larger public sectors. One can look at West Germany, Senator Martyr, which has an even greater deficit that we have when compared with the gross domestic product. Particularly in the welfare field they are far more generous than we are. There is no correlation between the size of the public sector and the economic performance of these countries. There is no correlation between the size of the public sector and the freedom and ability of people in these countries to control and develop their own lives.
—What is your authority?

—The OECD papers. I shall quote them any time and produce them for the honourable senator. The determination is, in fact-Senator Martyr is well known for this-to turn back the clock to the mythical, good old days when so-called market forces and a lack of government intervention will somehow bring us a new paradise. It ignores the historical reasons for the development of these services. Public services in this and other Western countries were developed because they were not provided. Those services were not provided by the private sector because it was either unwilling to do so or unable to do so at a cost which some citizens, through no fault of their own, could afford.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of public health and public health care in general, there had developed a general acceptance of the community rating principle whereby it was believed that, because the need for such care was by and large out of the control of the patient, the citizen, and that no civilised nation should fail to provide access to health care for all citizens, we should, in fact, have the principle of community rating. I have heard the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who is in the chamber tonight espouse that view in this place. This government has broken this principle. It wishes to introduce what is called the user pays principle, the end result of which inevitably is that the chronically ill and the large families with children who need health care more often than others, will pay more than the more fortunate people in the community and they will have less access to health care. They will be limited in their access to health care by financial means. As an aside, it is worthwhile remembering that the United States of America spends a higher percentage of its gross domestic product on health care than do the other Western democracies, and with great inequities and with no better results-in fact, with worse results in most cases.

This action and other actions of the Government represent an attack on public sector expenditure and public sector services, which means, in fact, an attack on the living standards of the disadvantaged members of this community. There can be no getting away from that. The actions represent an attack on the opportunities for such citizens to take part in society fully and to gain access to adequate housing, adequate health care and to a system of justice and education. In other words, this is an attack on their ability to improve their lot. We often hear, as a justification for withdrawal from the public sector in this way, that taxes can be reduced thereby increasing the freedom of some of us to spend our own income. But under this Government and under other governments which have taken similar action, these tax cuts inevitably occur so that the high income earners get the greatest benefit from the taxation cuts. That is, in fact, what happened in the last two series of tax cuts in this country. So the more affluent marginally increase their freedom to spend their money, whereas the withdrawal of services and at times the withdrawal of income from the poor-that has occurred also under this Government, in particular to the single unemployed and the young unemployed-represent an even greater attack on their freedom of choice. Such moves represent a great attack on the freedom of choice of the poorest in the community to make decisions which affect their own lives. Small cuts in income to the poor and the withdrawal of services to them severely restrict the freedom and the ability to act of the poor migrant, of the unemployed, of the supporting mother and of the low income family.

It is said that this argument-Senator Walters repeated it-which has arisen from this Government's philosophy and from the philosophy which is espoused in this document is in fact an argument about big government versus small government. It is not. It is an argument between a fair society and an efficient and an adequate government and a divided society and an uncaring government. To revert to the sort of laissez-faire state that Senator Martyr and his colleagues apparently wish to return to is to return to the times of public squalor and private affluence. This will be the inevitable result if we have a government which is, as this Government is, hostile and indifferent to the public sector and which at the same time encourages and subsidises some sections of the private sector. Such an outlook ignores the historical development of our society and it results, I suggest, from a very blinkered view of the world.

We can look at some of the statements in the document which superficially are unobjectionable and which superficially can be accepted by all sorts of people but which, when considered in conjunction with the actions of this Government, in fact are not much help at all to the community. We hear that only individuals have full knowledge of their own needs, wants and priorities and that politicians, officials and bureaucrats do not have this knowledge and can never have it. Apart from the simplistic nonsense represented in the statement which ignores the fact that politicians, officials and bureaucrats are themselves individuals, the statement ignores the fact that individuals have needs which they express such as the need for accessible health care and, in the case of migrants, the need for interpreters and for child care facilities. But what is the point of such knowledge if the services are not available or if politicians do what politicians in this Government do and ignore those needs? Another comment from the statement is: We are all better off in a social, political and material sense by limiting government. This may be so in some degree but not if it inflicts unnecessary austerity and unnecessary hardship on people because of lack of government services and lack of government support. One of the interesting comments in the statement is: The benefits of our program are now visible for everyone to see. How visible are they to those who are becoming unemployed in greater numbers than ever before? How visible are they to those who have been confused by five changes to the health system, who are unable to get care and who are uncertain about how to go about preparing to get that care. How visible are they to those on low incomes who have seen their family allowances eroded in value by some 60 per cent? These people have been badly treated by this much vaunted program. I suggest that if the Government continues in its present vein those people will continue to be badly treated.

Let us look briefly at some of the aspects of the Government's program which have arisen out of this document and out of recent statements in this Parliament. Senator Walters, when she was not attacking Senator Button, Senator Evans and other honourable senators on this side of the chamber for things they did not say and making her own interpretation of what people think and what people say, spent her whole time talking about the health system. The simple fact, as has been pointed out not only by the Opposition but also by obvservers in this community-by people involved in health care-is that the changes will result in less efficiency. They will result in less efficiency despite the five changes that preceded them and despite the half a million dollars which was spent, for instance, on the Jamison report into the efficiency of hospitals in this country. The whole direction of the health system now is to prop up the private health funds, to extend the private hospital services, to extend the private fee-for-service system to the detriment of the public hospital system and to remove the access of all people to the public hospital out-patient specialist facilities and in-patient facilities in this country. It is no wonder that this statement has been greeted with great glee by the private health funds which, according to today's paper, expect some two million to three million more people to join their funds, those people having been forced into such funds, they believe, by the changes to the present system.

The user pays principle in health is inappropriate. It is only appropriate in a situation where the user and the seller have equal knowledge of the system. That does not occur in the health system. Patients have very little knowldege of what is being done to them and of what can be done to them. They have neither the technical knowldege nor the skills to make the sort of judgment that people who are buying ordinary materials can make. To suggest, as Senator Walters did, that by charging people in public hospitals they will become aware of the cost of health and therefore use the hospitals less, is nonsense. Patients do not put themselves into hospitals; docors put them into hospitals. To suggest that by charging people for pathological and diagnostic tests which are used in medical treatment in this day and age, this will mean that patients will somehow be able to control the costs and have some idea of the situation, is nonsense. Doctors order those tests. Patients do not understand what the tests are about and it is a brave patient who questions the necessity of such tests by any doctor. It is a false situation. It does not apply.

Senator Walters, to back up her words, talked about the increasing costs of health care in this community. She blamed those increasing costs of health care on the Labor Government and the Medibank system. The first investigations into the health insurance system in this country in fact were initiated by Mr Gorton and his Liberal-Country Party Government in 1969. They were continued by Mr McMahon and his Government until 1972. There was great concern then about increases in the costs of health care in this community. That concern continued through 1972 and into 1973 and 1974 when the Labor Government was in power. Health costs did rise and that is why the community came to accept the need for Medibank which was introduced in July 1975. The great increases in health costs in this country occurred before the introduction of Medibank. I am sure that Senator Martyr, being an astute man, will know that the increases in costs levelled out after the introduction of Medibank and as a result of it. It was, in fact, nothing to do with the Labor Government or with Medibank that caused that escalation in costs from 1969 to 1975.

We will shortly be debating legislation to effect changes to the present health system. This will be the sixth time that I, as the shadow spokesman in the Senate on health, will have to debate this issue. It will not be the last time, because the people in this community will again become dis- satisfied with the extraordinary increase in the cost of covering their own health care which will arise out of this system. They will also be concerned about the diminution of services in the public hospitals. The States will be dissatisfied. Senator Walters apparently believes that to transfer these functions from the Federal Government to the State governments in what she described as a careful economic measure is the proper thing to do and that it will somehow result in decentralisation. Is Perth to the people in the northern part of Western Australia any further away in real terms than Canberra is?

Tonight the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has been in the embarrassing situation of demonstrating that he considers it all a game. He gloated about having played a little trick on the Premiers, saying that it was not a serious business at all and that, if they had pushed him harder, they would have got more money. This whole exercise is not serious to the Prime Minister; it is a game. The Premiers, four of whom are of the same political persuasion as the Prime Minister, do not think it is a game.

To have a free society, and a society in which people can make these choices and judgments about which the Prime Minister is always going on, we need to have information on which to base community services. The Government, realising this and not wanting people to make judgments and to have this sort of knowledge, has immediately attacked the information services in the community in its statement. We are told that the capacity of the Government Printer is to be limited to that required for Parliament and the urgent confidential needs of government. The remaining work is to be transferred to the private sector and the Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops are to be leased to the private sector. This means that fewer reports will be printed because the market will be too small to make them viable commercial propositions. The private sector will not take on small runs of important statistical and research material because it will be unprofitable. In order to be profitable, the bookshops will have to take on more commercial and less informative books; otherwise they will close. There will be a clamping down on information in this area. It will be more difficult for people to make the sorts of judgments that we should be able to make in this society.

In the area of employment and youth affairs, regular collections and publication of Commonwealth Employment Service statistics on persons registered for unemployment and on unfilled vacancies will be discontinued. The registered unemployed will be part of the hidden unemployed. We will no longer know what proportion of the registered unemployed is receiving benefits, what proportion falls into certain age groups and so on. We will not know where they are. We will have to rely on the Bureau of Statistics figures, samples for which are too small to indicate just where these people live, what people's ages are and what percentage of juniors will be unemployed in sections of Tasmania or South Australia.

The whole issue will be clouded. We will have to rely on Bureau of Statistics figures, which are not only based on a very small sample but also allow a large margin of error. For instance, the Bureau of Statistics estimate of 6,000 unemployed in Tasmania involves a standard error of plus or minus 530 people. We will not know the regional figures in that decentralised State-the figures for Burnie, Launceston or Hobart. We will just have gross figures for the State. Of course, that is what the Government wants. It does not want to make public the sorts of details which are so embarrassing and which have become increasingly embarrassing to it in the last five or six years.

In the area of immigration and ethnic affairs, the production of certain publications is to be terminated and the production of others is to be rationalised. The information role of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is to be rationalised. As we all know, the word 'rationalisation' is a euphenism for being reduced or cut out. Funding for the National Groups Directory is to be discontinued. This is not only a restriction on information; it is also a restriction on the ability of groups to communicate with one another, to know who is doing what in the field and to know how to get in touch with groups with similar backgrounds and similar interests. The Directory is a unique publication. No other directory can take its place. How much will this small saving to the Government cost the community?

In the Treasury, certain lower priority statistical collections are to to eliminated or reviewed in conjunction with the States and the frequency of other collections is to be reviewed. But no details are given. Will we continue to receive educational, child care, health survey and other social publications? Will the social indicators which so many people find so useful continue to be published? It is quite clear that the Government has decided that the less people know the better. This information rundown is not accidental. It is part of the dictatorial style of the Government. It is part of the principle that the less the public knows the better it is for the government in power. If we turn to the Attorney-General's Department, with which I am sure Senator Evans will deal later, we find that the Legal Aid Commission is to be abolished. We find that the Crown Solicitor's Division will let out more work to the private sector. This will inevitably mean higher Government costs. We have only to look at the costs to the Government of the recent Greek conspiracy case, which have been listed carefully and which may be referred to by others later.

In the area of employment and youth affairs, changes are to be made to the work test. Unemployment benefit forms and fortnightly income statements are to be returned directly to the Department of Social Security. All registered unemployed people will now be interviewed after four months' registration and the under-25 year olds will be re-interviewed after eight month's registration. This would seem to be a liberalisation of the work test and therefore of benefit and to be welcomed by many people, but in fact it is a recognition by the Government that the unemployment rate is high, will remain high and that the Government cannot do much about it. As an inevitable result of this the number of social workers and people who assist the unemployed, and the availability of assistance to the unemployed, will be reduced. After questioning Senator Chaney in the Senate and in the Estimates Committee, we have no idea of just how the new work test is to work. Senator Chaney admits that the Government has not worked it out yet. That is another scheme in this program which has not been thought through by the Government.

The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has been affected, again by small changes but in vital places, by a Government which frequently proclaims its interests in the ethnic communities in this country. The Assisted Passage Scheme is to be terminated forthwith. The production of publications is to be terminated in some cases and rationalised in others. The Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications will involve the introduction of charges for the examination of qualifications. Again, this is an example of the user pays principle. Is it appropriate in this situation? The migrant hostel management is to be transferred to the private sector on a management fee basis. What control will the Government keep over conditions in hostels and charges to migrants and refugees? What virtue, if any, is there in handing this function over to private enterprise, when the responsibility is quite clearly the Government's? What virtue is there in handing over these people to private enterprise, the main concern of which in this area is to make a profit?

The Commonwealth's role in the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program is to be restricted to arranging and co-ordinating only by relinquishing responsibility for the conduct of individual programs. This is a backward step. The program has been successful because the Federal Government has paid people to take time off work to learn language and communication skills. It has been one of the most successful Commonwealth programs. It is one which we wish to have extended to married women, who would have had less pressure to go into the job market if they had been helped to attend migrant education classes. The States will certainly not be able to take over this function. We suggest that it is foolish to have a migrant education program and then cut funds on the settlement side. It is an abdication of responsibility towards people whom the Commonwealth has wanted to attract. The translation and interpreting services are to be cut. The Telephone Interpreter Service, so vital to many people, should be expanded and not contracted as this document suggests. The Australian Ethnic Affairs Council, the Australian Population and Immigration Council and the Australian Refugees Advisory Council are to be replaced by a single advisory council. This is surely not streamlining. They have different functions entirely; they have developed different skills. Such action does not assist the migrants.

All areas have experienced cuts which will affect services to people who need them. The services will not be taken up by the States. The cuts will limit the ability of people to make choices about their own lives and to advance themselves in our society. That is a backward step. It demonstrates quite clearly, as Senator Walters said, the philosophical difference between the Government and Opposition parties. It shows the difference between a caring party and an uncaring party. It shows the difference between a party which wishes to follow the Western traditions of citizens being assisted by government and not return to the economic law of the jungle, the sort of social Darwinism which preceded us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence my speech in detail I add my congratulations to those of Senator Grimes to Senator Bjelke-Petersen on her maiden speech in this chamber tonight. It was a well delivered and thought-out speech. Senator Bjelke-Petersen once again put on record the role that Queensland plays in this Commonwealth. It is a role that I think the rest of the country is apt to forget every so often. We need a speech like that of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's to remind the rest of the people of the contribution that Queensland, which is the State which Senator Bjelke-Petersen and I represent, makes to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the most important aspect of her speech was when she mentioned the motto 'Advance Australia'. She said that she is an Australian who happens to live in Queensland. I think that is a pretty important thing. We are all apt to be a bit parochial at times. I must confess that every so often I am not averse to giving a serve to New South Welshmen or Victorians. But we must remember that we rise or fall as Australians, and that is a pretty good thing for us always to remember. Do not let us take our parochialism too far. We are Australians first.

Tonight I follow Senator Grimes, which is a new step for me. He mentioned the fact that he usually follows Senator Walters. Most of my contributions in this chamber are on the subject of transport and therefore I follow Senator Gietzelt. Senator Grimes and I do not usually talk on the same subjects. However, on this occasion we are considering the Government paper on the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Senator Grimes instanced the fact that he had just returned from a conference overseas. We are privileged at times to represent our country at international forums, whether it be the one that Senator Grimes has just attended, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, or the Inter-Parliamentary Union. We are privileged to attend those forums and to represent Australia.

One thing that I have learned from undertaking similar trips is what a great country Australia is to live in. It is a great country. There is no other country in which I should like to live permanently. Even though we live here, we have constantly to stop and take stock of our situation and to see whether we can improve things. I believe that the Commonwealth Government in this Review of Commonwealth Functions or, as it has become affectionately known, the report of the razor gang, has done just that. It has stopped and taken stock of its situation. It has stopped to take a look at itself and started to review its activities to see whether it should continue in a certain vein or whether improvements should be made. It has looked to see whether some jobs that it is doing can be done better by other sections of the community. Of course we must never forget the fact that we are but stewards of the taxpayers' money. We just handle it. It is a tremendous responsibility to see that we handle that money as best we can, that we exercise stewardship and that we get the best results from it. By getting the best results we will ultimately require less from the taxpayers to fund the various projects and organisations that a Commonwealth government finds itself having to fund. We would be abrogating our responsibilities if we did not do so. This is the first instance in my memory in which such a review has been undertaken, but I hope it is not the last one. I hope it will be an on-going thing and that we will continue to stop and take stock of our situation and recognise our stewardship.

It is quite obvious that projects that may have been started in the Commonwealth sphere can now be abandoned. They may be done better by the States or by private enterprise. If that is the situation, let us handle it properly and move those functions into whatever sphere is required to see that the taxpayers' money is used most wisely. That means that we need less government control. It is not the Government's role to dabble its fingers in every aspect of the life of the citizens of this great country. The Government is there to provide good government, and that is all. If there is not a requirement for it to be in a certain situation or to do a certain job that it has done in the past, then let it get out. Many advisory committees have been set up in the past, and many advisory committees will be set up in the future. But once their function is concluded, let us disband them. Let us not, as has happened in the past when they have completed their functions, let them look around and find something else to do. In the meantime other advisory committees are set up. They multiply. When these committees have finished their functions, let us say: 'Thank you very much; you have done your job; you are now disbanded'. We must do that so that we do not have a proliferation of committees.

Some measures have been taken in the Australian Capital Territory which I must confess I am not really up with. One thing I am surprised that the Government did not do-this is always a cause of concern to many of us-is look at selling the Australian Capital Territory bus service. I do not begrudge the citizens of the Capital Territory a bus service. On the contrary, I am all in favour of efficient bus services. That is the most efficient way of using fuel and energy. But I think some other section of the community could run the service more efficiently, particularly when we look at the burgeoning losses.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens with the Canberra bus service is that the buses get run down and they are sold.

—Maybe they do get run down. Maybe they get run down because we do not give enough assistance. We pour millions of dollars into the public sector for buses. The same applies to the rail transport sector. I have no quarrel with that. But if a private bus service is doing a good job it should be allowed to continue. In Brisbane, my State capital, private bus services which were making money have been taken over; they are now losing money. If there is a requirement for the bus service to be continued under private ownership, let the Government provide a subsidy instead of allowing it to continue as a local government or State function and pour money into an almost bottomless pit.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no quarrel with the reduction in the Public Service. One thing does worry me, as indeed it worried me when the cut-back in funds to the Australian Broadcasting Commission was first mentioned some considerable time ago. I think the Government should have more control over the reduction of the numbers of public servants. I do not think we are really cutting out the fat. All we are doing is saying to the heads of the departments: 'This is your staff ceiling' and leaving it to them. I think that every head of every department is a little empire builder and somehow or other he is managing not to get rid of the fat. He is probably cutting out the lower echelons, and it is usually the lower echelons in the Public Service who are providing service to the community and manning the counters and meeting the public face to face. That part of the Public Service appears to be suffering most. I think that the Commonwealth Government ought to pay more attention to this matter and make sure that the services are provided. Maybe it should look more intently at the fat that is usually evident in the middle echelon so that services are maintained at the same time as staff ceilings are reduced, thus not putting such a burden on the taxpayers.

I will mention but a few of the things-I will certainly not go through the whole list- that the Government said it wants to look at. Firstly, it wants a public inquiry into Telecom Australia. I do not see this, and never have done, as a chance to bash Telecom. Indeed, on many occasions I have gone in to bat for it. I admit that it is having problems. Anybody who has to provide a communications service in a country such as Australia which has its population situated where it is and who tries to provide it to those who need it most will have lots of trouble. Telecom, like the Government, is a massive organisation. It has done well. It has probably done more than any other private enterprise to reduce charges over recent years and at the same time it has increased the number of connections that it is providing. In certain areas the population is growing in excess of what Telecom has budgeted for and it is already having problems with its equipment not being able to handle the loads. So I welcome an inquiry into Telecom. That will enable it to stop and take stock of the situation. It does not have to be a witch hunt or anything like that. But Telecom should stop and look at itself. It should critically survey the situation and see whether its money can be better spent; see whether there can be a better deployment of staff so that we can provide the necessary communications service for the vast distances in Australia.

Another area which has been subject to review is education. Nobody would doubt at any time that governments, both State and Federal, are responsible to provide education. I believe that we are accepting that responsibility. But ultimately those within the education system must remember who pays the Bill. Undoubtedly there are benefits for society if all people are educated, but it is hard to pinpoint the benefits for taxpayers of educating the people who are termed professional students or the bored housewives who just want to get another degree. I have no quarrel with their doing that; that is their business. But I do not believe that it is the taxpayers' responsibility to fund the education of those people. We have a responsibility to fund the education of people who use that education to make their way in life, but the professional students or the bored housewives seeking to update their previous qualifications should foot the bill for their education. Let the taxpayers be responsible for those who will contribute to society. I would encourage the others to further their education but let them pay their fees.

Above all, we must assure students, some of whom are quite concerned at this stage, that it is not our desire to prevent young people from receiving a tertiary education if they desire to make their way in this world. We have not said otherwise. We have said of necessity at times that there will be a tightening up in the allowances paid to them. However, there has been some misunderstanding regarding persons studying for a second degree. If a second degree is required for a person's professional status it will be regarded as part of the deal and they will not be charged tertiary fees. We have also mentioned the loans scheme. That is not a bad idea for the young people who want to go further and who do not meet certain requirements. At least they will be able to do that and then pay back to the society what they have taken from it for their education.

Let us look briefly at health matters. Dr Glen Sheil, a former senator, used to say that the use of anything that is free at the point of demand usually rises astronomically. That is particularly so in the case of health matters. Over a period we have forgotten that the body has its own recuperative powers. Once we would take an aspirin and go to bed or work, but it seems that when a visit to a doctor is free it is a good excuse to go there.

Let us examine health expenditure from 1972 until this point in time. I have the full figures but maybe the percentages will suffice. From 1972-73 to 1973-74 there was an increase of 20 per cent in the expenditure. We were not in government at that time. The Australian Labor Party was in government and it was building up towards Medibank. From 1973-74 to 1974-75 we saw an increse in health expenditure of 37.3 per cent. The next year it was down to 13.2 per cent. In 1978-79 the increase in expenditure was only 9.3 per cent. There is no doubt that when somebody else picks up the tab it is very easy to use or misuse the system. We firmly believe that a user who can afford to pay should pay. We have stipulated from the beginning that those who cannot afford to pay for themselves will be looked after by the Government. That has been spelt out in the Government's statement. Those who cannot afford to pay certainly will not want for good health treatment, but those who can afford will have to pay their bit towards maintaining their section of the health scheme.

—The Jamison report has shown that Queensland has one of the most efficient health schemes in Australia on a cost basis.
—Because it has got rid of fee for service more than anybody else has.

—It is because it has a very good private hospital system which has kept everyone honest. But we have to ensure that Queensland, because of its past efficiencies, is not disadvantaged; that its relativities are maintained. That is something that my colleagues and I from Queensland will be watching very closely in regard to the split-up. As far as the free hospital scheme goes, the Commonwealth Government is saying straight out to the Queensland Government or any other government: 'You can do what you like. It is your business'. I go along with that. If Queensland, New South Wales or Western Australia wants to maintain or introduce a free health scheme, so be it. I see my role here as making sure that, because of Queensland's efficiencies in the past, its relativities are maintained, that it is not disadvantaged because of those efficiencies and that it gets an equal share of the cake in the split up.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has also initiated a few changes in the transport field. One that comes to mind is the deregulation of the Australian National Railways to allow it to operate on a competitive basis. About two years ago the Government said to ANR that it hoped that in 10 years' time its revenue would exceed its expenditure. It is a credit to ANR and all its staff that they are going a long way towards achieving that objective. I think it is an example of another situation in which the Government should suggest to the States that they also should stop and take stock. Last year the railway systems in Australia lost $1,000m. In other words, $1 billion of taxpayers' money cannot be accounted for except in respect of the activities of the ANR. It is time that the States also stopped and had a look at the running of their services because that is one heck of a lot of money. I have no quarrel about subsidies being provided for railway services provided they are run efficiently and they are not used in competition with other modes of transport that are competing commercially. The railways deficit is a lot of taxpayers' money. I congratulate the ANR and the staff on what they have achieved up to this point. I hope they can keep up that sort of work.

As far as the departmental oversight of Qantas is concerned, I can only welcome the fact that the Department of Transport is getting out of that area. Last financial year Qantas lost about $20m. About $15m of that can be attributed to the Department of the Treasury insisting on how or where Qantas borrowed its money. Qantas got caught in the revaluation of certain currencies. If Treasury keeps its hands off Qantas and lets Qantas make its own commercial judgment in that sphere it can only be to the betterment of the travelling public. Also, if the Department of Transport keeps its hands further away from Qantas the airline might be better off. I understand that the Government is to allow Qantas to make its own tariff arrangements. Having spoken with some of the officials of Qantas I understand that they do not want a minimum fare set by any government. All they want is a maximum fare and capacity arrangements. They maintain that Qantas can quite easily compete with other international airlines which fly into and out of Australia. I would like to see Qantas given a free hand so that it can make its own commercial judgment and set its own fares to enable our flag carrier to compete not only around the world but in and out of Australia, which it is finding very hard to do with the heavy hand of the Department of Transport resting on it.

In regard to airports, maybe if the domestic and international airlines had more say in the running of our terminals we would not have some of the big monoliths that have been built, albeit with the best of intentions and at great cost which is recouped through air navigation charges. If the domestic airlines are able to build their own terminals maybe we will have something that is a bit more efficient in the long run and certainly more cost effective and with fewer charges coming back to the fare-paying public. As far as the local ownership plan is concerned, I know that many local government authorities find it hard to come to grips with this plan, but once again, provided the Commonwealth Government is prepared to assist them with maintenance, I understand that-

TALK.START.PARA: —What about TAA?

—The honourable senator has heard my statements in this place many times in relation to Trans-Australia Airlines. It does not actually come up in this debate. I think many local government authorities should look seriously at taking up this Government's offer on local ownership because certainly a government which owns an airfield and administers it from Canberra, albeit through State capitals, is only interested in running the airport, whereas if local government took over an airport it could certainly make it into an entree to that area. It could use it as the tourist entrance and do something about it, which certainly will not be done as long as it is owned and administered by the Federal Government from a great distance. I welcome the proposal that the Government will assist local authorities with maintenance but the local bodies should take over the airports and make something of them. As I said, they could make them into a good tourist entrance to their area. One such airport is Mackay, which is the entrance to the Whitsunday area and the Great Barrier Reef. It is generally recognised that most of the tourists who come into resorts fly in. Any local government that gets hold of an airport can certainly make something of it. I know that people in Cairns are trying to do something. They are now welcoming international passengers who are coming to Cairns from Port Moresby by Air Niugini. I know these people are looking at ways in which they can take over the airport. I welcome the fact that businessmen, the community and local government authorities have the initiative to want to take over these airports, to make something of them and to use them for the benefit of the tourist trade in their area.

SPEECH.PARA: It certainly gives me a lot of pleasure to support the Government in this initiative. As I said at the outset, I think governments, not only our Government but also State governments, should all the time stop and take stock of the situation. We are but stewards of the taxpayers, money. We have to make sure that that money is spent wisely and that the taxpayer is getting good value for his money. I believe that is what the Government is trying to do now. We get continual calls for a reduction in taxes, and I guess that is natural. If some other section in the community can do something more efficiently, well let it and let us use the taxpayers, money as efficiently as we can and ultimately take the least possible tax off them. I support the Government in these initiatives.

In a subsequent statement to this Parliament the former Minister for Industrial Relations made a number of statements about the conduct of the Prime Minister. Earlier tonight in a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders pursuant to Standing Order 448, I sought to establish in connection with another matter that there was urgent necessity in relation to the need for that motion to be discussed. In the course of establishing urgent necessity, as I saw it, I was interrupted on a number of occasions, if I may say so with respect, Mr President, by your saying: 'You must not debate the merits of the matter, you must not debate the issue, you must not deal with the subtance, you can address your remarks only to the points of urgent necessity'. On four occasions I acceded to your ruling and directed my remarks to points of urgent necessity, in the words of Standing Order 448, rather than to the substance of the matter which I wanted to debate at a subsequent stage, if my motion had been carried. Now that the motion for the adjournment of the Senate has been put, I want to make some remarks about the substance of the matter which would have been discussed if my motion had been carried. Mr President, I remind you that on a number of occasions you invited me not to deal with the substance and I acceded to your ruling. I dealt with questions of urgent necessity. I now want to deal with--

TALK.START.PARA: —And, rightly, you have to do that.
—On a point of order, Mr President, I draw your attention to a stranger in the chamber who is conducting himself in an ungentlemanly manner by waving his hands around.

—I am indebted to Senator Young. I now want to deal with a number of matters relating to the conduct of this Government and the way in which the Prime Minister conducts the affairs of the Government and of the nation. I want to do so in the context of referring to the conduct of the affairs of this nation in relation to the recent Premiers Conference. It is well known that prior to the recent Premiers Conference the Prime Minister made a number of macho statements about the tough line the Government would take with the Premiers when they came to Canberra. That is very interesting, but tonight on television I heard the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the Fraser Government saying that he made a number of remarks to the Press subsequent to that Premiers Conference because the Government had said things which it did not mean-they were the Treasurer's words-in relation to the Premiers Conference which was coming up and which was finally held last Monday. It is an extraordinary statement for a Treasurer to say that a government says publicly to the Premiers of the six States of the Commonwealth things that it does not mean. That was the comment of the Treasurer tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Premiers Conference, which is of utmost concern to the system of government in this country and which is, in the words of government senators on many occasions, a very important forum for arriving at conclusions on the so called co-operative federalism or the new federalism, whatever we like to call it, was held last Monday. In the course of the Premiers Conference there was an agreement between the national Government and the Premiers that the States would receive a 9 per cent increase in tax reimbursements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, I think the matters to which you wish to refer had better be approached with a substantive motion. You are really getting back to that which you were aiming to discuss tonight when you sought the suspension of Standing Orders. You must not continue the debate on that matter.

—I raise a point of order. When Senator Button was speaking to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, Senator Peter Baume on a couple of occasions took a point of order and asked you, Mr President, to request Senator Button to confine his remarks to the reasons why Standing Orders should be suspended. You did so. Senator Button continued. You did not stop him continuing. You therefore agreed that he was confining his remarks to the reasons for the suspension of Standing Orders. We are now on the adjournment debate. The only motion before the Chair before the adjournment debate was the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. Senator Button is now speaking to a substantial matter which involves this country and which involves a State Premier of the same party as the Prime Minister and the Treasurer calling for the resignation of the Treasurer. In no way can Senator Button be said to be bringing up matters which he had brought up just before the adjournment debate. To try to stop him from debating this matter is a perversion of the functions of this chamber. If we are to proceed in this way we will be limiting discussion of important issues on the adjournment debate in future, which I suggest will be a perversion of Standing Orders. Mr President, I suggest that you must allow Senator Button to continue with the substantive issue that he is talking about.

—I agree with Senator Peter Baume that Senator Button cannot debate the matter that he wished to debate when he moved for the suspension of Standing Orders. I admire Senator Button's legal approach. I am not a legal man myself. I want to see things done correctly in this place. All I am saying is that Senator Button should not revive matters raised in a previous debate. I concede to a point that the actual substance of the matter he wished to raise was not debated because of adherence to my requests that he should not debate it in speaking to the motion to suspend Standing Orders. I ask Senator Button to continue and I will listen very closely to him.

—May I say by way of explanation that I did not in any way seek to pursue any legal point as a result of my misfortune in having had legal training. What I was seeking to say, with respect, Mr President, was that you in the chair as a Government senator cannot have it both ways. You cannot stop me speaking about the substance of an issue when I move a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders and then subsequently say that again I cannot speak about the substance of an issue which I did not speak about on the first occassion. With respect, that is the point.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am seeking to do is to establish a number of facts first and then I will be seeking to pursue an argument in relation to those facts. I refer to the facts again. It is not, with respect, a question of identifying subject matters and then saying that they are the same things as were dealt with in the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. I made the point that after the Premiers Conference, at 11 p.m., after the Premiers had gone home, in an off the record briefing with the Press, a favourite Fraser Government ministerial device, the Treasurer, Mr Howard, said that if the States had been more resolute they would have received an extra one per cent. By that he meant they would have received an extra $70m which was lost to them as a result of the failure of the present Government to be frank with them about the money which was available. The State of New South Wales would have received an extra $19m.

Last night Malcolm Fraser, the Prime Minister of this country, saw journalists from the Herald and Weekly Times group of newspapers-the Sun-Pictorial, the Sydney Morning Herald, the West Australian and the Courier-Mail. In the course of that interview the Prime Minister boasted that the Cabinet-the Cabinet of Dr Caligari, as it might be called, rather than the Cabinet of Malcolm Fraser, before the Premiers had even met, had decided that the States could get one per cent more than he and the Treasurer in fact gave them. That was decided by Cabinet beforehand.

That story, needless to say, was published in editions of those newspapers arising from a background briefing. Ministers of this Government do not hold frank and open Press conferences anymore, at least until tonight. The Prime Minister does not hold frank and open Press conferences. He has his curbside chats in the mornings, but does not subject himself to questioning, other than Dorothy Dix questions, by journalists. In this background briefing that boast was made by the Prime Minister and it was published in the newspapers. This morning the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the national broadcasting service of this country, asked for an interview with the Prime Minister. In the meantime the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, had made a statement saying that the action of the Prime Minister at the Premiers Conference was directed at giving a tax cut by the Federal Government before the next election. Mr Wran bought into the argument to that extent.

Next in the sequence of events, the ABC and the commercial television stations asked the Prime Minister about the leaked story of the Commonwealth retaining the one per cent-the $70m-which should have gone to the Premiers of the States. The newspaper stories attributed the leak to a senior Government official. The Prime Minister got very angry when he was asked questions about that. Anybody who saw him on the ABC television news tonight could see that he got very angry. There was all that stuff spoken in eighteenth century English meaning: 'If you want to ask me questions you have to tell me precisely what the questions are before I will even see you so that I can get an answer'. He refused to answer questions of which he had not been given prior notice. This is the macho Prime Minister of Australia who outbid, defeated and deceived the Premiers in respect of the money which was available to them. The reason why he got angry was that he was the senior Government official described in the Press. Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, has become-now you see him, now you do not-a senior Government official. That was his pseudonym, his nom de plume for those stories which were leaked in the Press.

In the meantime, Sir Charles Court, who also reads the newspapers, saw the reports about the States being cheated of an extra one per cent and promptly called for Treasurer Howard's resignation. Howard was later interviewed on the PM program. He was asked whether Fraser was the source of the story and the senior Government official, so described. He was asked about Premier Court's comments. Howard refused to deny that the Prime Minister of Australia was masquerading as a senior Government official. Howard, the Treasurer of Australia, refused to deny that the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, was the source of these leaked stories to the Press.

Those Government senators who have a vivid command of events in their own party will remember that it is only 14 days since the Prime Minister was accused by a former senior Minister of leaking stories to the Press about him. On this occasion he leaked stories to the Press about how he had outsmarted the Premiers of the six States of Australia. He leaked those stories under the guise of being a senior Government official. Mr Howard refused to say anything about Premier Court's call for his resignation. He waffled about that issue. Mr Howard later tried to get the ABC AM producer in Sydney to stop that interview going to air. Mr David Barnett, a person of some notoriety-if I might say that without putting it too highly-went to the ABC office in the Press Gallery three times and tried to stand over the chief of staff of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the national broadcasting service, to get him to kill the story of the interview with Fraser.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure of that?

—Yes, I am absolutely sure of that. Mr Barnett did that because the Prime Minister was very embarrassed that he had been caught. Mr Howard, the Treasurer of Australia, looks after our money and saves us $70m by cheating the six State Premiers. We had a debate in the Senate about whether the expression 'having one's fingers in the till' is a legitimate charge to make against this Government. The man who looks after our money, Mr Howard, has his fingers in the till all the time. That is his job. He looks after our money and he saved us $70m by keeping it from the State Premiers.

SPEECH.PARA: At a Press conference this evening Mr Howard said, in essence: 'Look, I started all this. It was my fault. I leaked this information to the Press. You really ought to ask the Prime Minister a few questions too. You really ought to ask him a few questions about stories which were leaked to the Press.' That was the essence of what Mr Howard said on television tonight. An earlier Press conference of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, was also shown on television, and what he was trying to say was almost unintelligible. Treasurer Howard's statement on television tonight was a tragic thing. It is tragic to see a Minister in a government debasing himself publicly in this way. Some honourable senators will have read that great novel of Arthur Koestler entitled Darkness at Noon. Mr Howard was saying: 'Yes, it was my fault but the party must go on. It was my fault'. It was a case of darkness at noon for Mr Howard; darkness at noon for yet another Minister in the Fraser Government. The despicable sight of the Prime Minister of Australia on television this afternoon-Malcolm Fraser, the tough leader who cheated the Premiers of $70m-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator should be careful when talking about the Premiers being cheated.

—Malcolm Fraser who did not cheat the Premiers of $70m. Malcolm Fraser, the tough leader of the Liberal Party, the macho leader of this country, was there as a pathetic figure reminding one of that character the Duke of Plaza-Toro. Is this country now led by the Duke of Plaza-Toro? Do honourable senators remember what happened to him:

SPEECH.PARA: In enterprise of martial kind,
When there was any fighting,
He led his regiment from behind-
He found it less exciting.

That was what the Prime Minister of Australia was doing tonight-leading his regiment from behind when the going got tough. The saying goes: 'When the going gets tough, the toughs get going'. That is what happened to Malcolm Fraser tonight. There was nothing tough about him tonight. He got going, abandoned his Treasurer and left him hanging on a limb. He did exactly the same thing for his Treasurer as he did for Andrew Peacock three weeks ago. That is a crisis of government in this country.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate should come into the chamber as soon as possible-he is here now and has the opportunity to do so-to explain the situation to this House of Parliament and not do what was done in the House of Representatives, namely, seek to stop people speaking about this issue. This matter was dealt with on a special edition of Nationwide tonight. It will be in every newspaper in Australia tomorrow. But members of the House of Representatives cannot discuss this matter because the Liberal Government will not face up to it. It was scared to discuss this matter tonight and it gagged two senior Labor members in the House of Representatives to prevent them from raising this issue. The Leader of the Government in the Senate should explain what the Prime Minister of this country is really up to. That is what people throughout this country will be concerned to know tomorrow.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a crisis point in family planning funds been reached, which could result in the closure of some services.
(2) Does the uncertainty about funding threaten the job security of Family Planning Association (FPA) trained staff and the loss of experienced and effective people.
(3) Was the Tasmanian FPA unable to pay staff in November 1980 until the Minister for Health released funds for the month, and are funds available for the 1980-81 financial year still unknown.

(4) Will the Minister examine the possibility of triennial funding for FPA programs to achieve continuity and responsible financial management, thus ensuring the retention of staff trained for this vital community service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The State and Territory Family Planning Associations receive two forms of grant from the Department of Health-a health program grant, which is directed towards assisting the clinical activities of the Associations, and a family planning program grant which is directed towards assisting education, information and training programs, that is, non-clinical activities.

Notwithstanding the Commonwealth Government's budget strategy of continuing financial restraint and no growth in health services, it has been possible to increase the amount provided under both the family planning program and health program grant arrangements to enable broadly the continuation of existing levels of activities during 1980-81.

In the case of the family planning program, the 1980-81 level of grants reflected a minimum increase of 4 per cent over the 1979-80 grants. Approved health program grant budgets for 1980-81 provide for inflation factors of 8 per cent for salaries and wages and 9 per cent for all other items or such other amounts as are warranted to maintain activities at 1979-80 levels.

On this basis, and against the inescapable restraints imposed by the budget situation, there has been no crisis in funding for Family Planning Associations which could result in the closure of services previously funded during 1979-80.

It should be appreciated that while the Government has continued to make as large a contribution as possible to family planning activities, it has always been made clear to the Associations that there was no unlimited undertaking to underwrite those activities.

(2) and (3) The payment of interim family planning program grants in August and October 1980 enabled maintenance of the existing activities that attract this form of grant for all the Family Planning Associations during the first six months of 1980-81. The Family Planning Association of Tasmania was advised on 23 December 1980 of its total family planning program grant of $20,000 for 1980-81.

The Department delayed making recommendations to me concerning total family planning program grants for 1980-81 because of complications relating to the financial administration of two of the organisations funded under the program and the likelihood that resolution of these matters would enable grant increases to other organisations.

Health program grant funds are paid on a monthly basis with interim grants being made in the case of any delay in determining the appropriate level of grants for individual Associations. Associations are therefore assured of funds to the level of the approved budget being forthcoming each month under these arrangements.

However, some problems in relation to the health program grant for the Tasmanian Family Planning Association did occur as a result of budget estimating problems on the part of the Association (approved health programs grants are based on budgets submitted by each Association). Upon my Department becoming aware of this problem further health program grant funds were quickly provided, on an interim basis, and the Association was requested to review its budget. I understand that some problem did arise in the meantime as to payment of salary of one staff member.

Health program grant allocations for 1980-81 for the various Associations have been determined and advised to the Associations but are, in some cases, being reviewed in the light of requests for additional funds.

(4) A triennial system of funding is not possible as the family planning program and the health program grant arrangements, like other health funding programs, are based on the annual appropriation of funds in the Commonwealth Budget. Consequently, annual approval is necessary for grants made under the program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role does the Government play to ensure that Telecom and Australia Post provide the most effective services possible, particularly in remote areas?
(2) Why is the telegram delivery service at Atherton, a fairly large town in North Queensland, being terminated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Postal Services Act 1975 (Section 7) and the Telecommunications Act 1975 (Section 6) both contain provisions requiring the Australian Postal Commission and the Australian Telecommunications Commission respectively to perform their functions in such a manner as best meets the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian people for those services. Each Commission is required, in so far as reasonably practical, to make its services available throughout Australia for all people who reasonably require those services.
In providing services each authority is required to have regard to:
(1) the desirability of improving and extending its services in the light of developments in the field of communications;
(2) the need to operate its services as efficiently and economically as practicable and
(3) the special needs for such services of Australian people who reside or carry on business outside the cities.

Provision exists in each Act (section 8 and section 7 respectively) for the Minister, after consultation with the Commission, to give to the Commission, in writing, such directions, with respect to the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers, as appear to the Minister to be necessary in the public interest.
(2) I am informed that there are no plans to terminate the telegram delivery service at Atherton.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What standards are enforced concerning the amount of X-radiation emitted from television sets, video display units, poker machines and other games which use television tubes.
(2) Has it been established whether or not the foetuses of pregnant women are affected by the women's exposure to radiation emitted from colour television sets.

(3) Have there been any cases where children playing around television sets have been affected by radiation emission; if so, will the Government ensure that producers of these units make certain radiation is kept below the safety standard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In October 1975, the National Health and Medical Research Council recommended for adoption by the States, standards relating to radiation emission from television receivers. The Standards Association of Australia also has a standard on 'Electronic Sound and Vision Equipment' which gives the same radiation emission limits. This would apply to television receivers, visual display units, poker machines and other games using television tubes. The methods of testing recommended by each document differ slightly. Each State decides whether to include recommended standards in its legislation.

However, tests made on television receives show that radiation near the prescribed limits can only be detected under extreme fault conditions, (when viewable pictures are not sustained for any length of time). Tests on over 100 different models of visual display units show no measurable levels of radiation and accordingly are well within the standards set. Tests have not been carried out on poker machines and other television games, but as they use television tubes, their radiation levels should be no greater than from television receivers and visual display units.
In Victoria and New South Wales at least, each model of television receiver is monitored by electrical authorities before marketing. Local manufacturers and assemblers also do their own monitoring.

(2) Doses received by television viewers are extremely low. Estimates made in the United Kingdom are that the annual per caput dose equivalent from colour television is 0.002 microsievert. This is one two millionth part of the radiation received normally from natural background radiation.

(3) There have been no reported cases of children having been affected by radiation emission from television receivers. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, high emission rates were reported from the bases of some colour television receivers in the United States of America. These were caused by the rectifying valves used. Nowadays these have been replaced by solid state circuitry and such radiation emission is not possible with this.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 12 March 1981 (Hansard, page 566) Senator Elstob asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom Australia intends to introduce a fee of $10 for subscribers with silent numbers; that is, numbers not listed in telephone directories. Will the Minister intervene in this proposal especially on behalf of people such as members of the police force, women living alone, the legal profession, and others who may be victims of nuisance calls and who now will be punished by Telecom as well? Would it not be possible to publish in the directories the name of the subscriber, with the word 'unlisted' instead of the telephone number for persons wishing to retain a private number? Surely this scheme would save the telephone operators valuable searching time.
-The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am advised by Telecom that in line with telecommunications authorities world-wide, it is standard practice to encourage telephone subscribers to include their name, address and telephone number in the relevant telephone directory so that other people in the community who wish to contact them have at their disposal information with which to do so. Nevertheless, it is recognised that some subscribers, for privacy or other reasons, prefer that their name, address and number details not be listed. Telecom has informed me that it readily accepts such reasons and provides for silent line treatment but only after warning the applicant of the inconvenience and distress which can be occasioned to callers who genuinely desire the number in an emergency. In the case of severe nuisance calls, there are a number of services which Telecom will continue to provide without charge to assist in dealing with this problem.

Telecom indicated however that, contrary to what might generally be thought to be the case, silent line services actually increase rather than decrease its overall operating costs. Whilst there are minor savings in directory publication costs, considerable added expense is incurred in handling Directory Assistance enquiries generated as a result of subscribers not having a listing in the appropriate telephone directory. These enquiries generally take longer to handle because of the need to explain to the enquirer why no information can be provided even in cases of emergency.

In recent years an increasing number of customers have chosen to have an unlisted service and Telecom advises that it considers the stage has been reached where it is no longer fair and reasonable to expect subscribers generally to meet the consequential costs involved. It has been assessed that, for the year 1979-80, silent lines generated some 1.68 million calls to Directory Assistance at a cost to Telecom of about $1.12 million. Telecom has therefore decided to introduce an annual charge of $10 for silent line services, to be applied from the publication date in respect of all telephone directories issued after 1 July 1981. The fee of $10 compares favourably with those charged in other countries, eg. the Bell System in the USA at $US18 per annum, or the New Zealand charge of $NZ15 per annum.

Telecom has acknowledged that in certain circumstances, eg, in the case of some people in particular occupational groups, the silent line service may be considered a necessity. However, it is of the view that with services of this nature those subscribers who require them and benefit from their provision should make some contribution towards the costs incurred.

Concerning the possibility of publishing in the directories the name of the subscriber with the word 'unlisted' instead of the telephone number for a person wishing to have a silent line, this proposal is currently under consideration by Telecom following prior receipt of the same suggestion from another source. Telecom is researching the acceptability to silent line customers of this option, its likely effectiveness in reducing costs incurred through Directory Assistance and any problems there might be in implementing the suggestion. Telecom indicated that it will be some months before a decision is reached on the matter and, in the meantime, the charge of $10 per annum will be applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 April Senator Mason (Hansard, page 1209) asked me a question, without notice, concerning the management of radio-active materials in Australia. I undertook to check on arrangements for registration and cost recovery, and provide the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: The importation of radioactive materials is subject to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations Act and requires the approval of the Australian Radiation Laboratory (ARL) if the material is for medical use, or the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) for other uses.

Where the material is licensable under State legislation approvals to import are subject to possession of a State licence. Records of imported material are maintained by AAEC and ARL. In addition, the Commonwealth Air Navigation and Navigation Acts provide control over all the air transport of radionuclides, and international and interstate sea transport.

Control of radioactive materials within Australia is primarily a matter for States and Territory governments. The possession of radioactive materials is subject to their legislation either through specific Radiation Acts or through Regulations under Health Acts.

All States and the Northern Territory require institutions and/or individuals to be licensed, although materials below specified minimum activity levels may be exempted. Their legislation also covers labelling of containers of radioactive materials, and transport and disposal of radioactive materials. In the ACT, the Capital Territory Health Commission monitors the use of radioactive materials and a Radiation Ordinance is currently in preparation.
Co-ordination is achieved nationally through a number of expert groups:

(i) The National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) has a long established Radiation Health Committee to assess and review the levels of exposure of the public from radioactive substances and irradiating apparatus, and to recommend appropriate procedures for minimising such exposure, including the development of uniform codes of practice. For example, the code of practice on industrial gauges is currently being updated by the Committee. NH & MRC periodically makes recommendations to Governments on appropriate procedures to assist them in their implementation of their legislation relating to radioactive substances and irradiation.

(ii) Codes of practice are being developed by the Commonwealth under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory. A proposed code on transport of radioactive material has been forwarded to Ministers by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, and has been made available for public comment. It is intended that the code be adopted under State and Commonwealth law as appropriate.

(iii) In September 1979 the then Minister for National Development announced that the Commonwealth Government would be seeking the co-operation of State and Territory Governments in developing co-ordinated policies on the management of radioactive wastes arising from medical, research and industrial use of radionuclides. All are co-operating and the matter is under active consideration by officials.

Most of the imported radioactive materials and radioisotopes produced by AAEC are used in medical, research and industrial applications and not by the nuclear industry. As the possession of radioactive materials is subject to licences, which make provisions for fees, the mechanism exists for making users of radioactive substances pay for the cost of regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 April Senator O'Byrne (Hansard, page 1202) asked me a question without notice about what happened after an accident near Laurieton, New South Wales, to foodstuffs being carried on a truck which also carried radioactive materials and chemicals. I undertook to seek out action taken by the New South Wales authorities and provide the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: The New South Wales and Queensland health authorities have confirmed that inspections revealed no leakage of radioactive material from its container as a result of the accident. The New South Wales authority confirms that tests of soil and local water supplies near the accident site have not revealed contamination by chemicals.

The New South Wales authority confirms that packages of foodstuffs, damaged as a result of the accident, were buried at the site. Undamaged packages were forwarded on to Brisbane, and the New South Wales health authority subsequently informed its Queensland counterpart. I understand that State health authorities consider there is no need for further action to be taken on this matter.
